title: Computer Executives Seek Broader Federal Support
description: In what may be the next battle over Government support for a specific industry, a dozen top computer executives asked the Bush Administration today to broaden its current efforts to develop technology for a nationwide high-speed computing network.

title: German Aide Quits Over Role in Sending Weapons to Israelis
description: One of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's senior aides resigned today, partly in reaction to criticism over his role in the secret shipment of weapons to Israel.

title: Bijagua Journal; Graves Called Witness To Sandinista Atrocity
description: Down a steep slope and across a creek from a hilltop farmhouse, eight pits are waiting to offer up bitter fruit from Nicaragua's long war between the Sandinistas and the contra rebels.

title: Once More, Germany Tries to Obliterate an Uncomfortable Past; Neo-Nazi Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Intractable Trade Issues With Japan
description: For nearly a decade, Japan and the United States have labored to bridge their economic differences through a series of unusually intense trade negotiations. Despite occasional bitterness on both sides, they shared a belief that only a few barriers stood in the way of an even deeper economic alliance from which the whole world would benefit.

title: Public & Private; Trials and Truth
description: The statements are damning. One woman says he threw her over a couch and pinned her to the floor, using his weight to hold her supine. Another said he had a "ferocious . . . almost animal like kind of look to him" as she tried to push him off while he penetrated her. A third remembers an ordinary conversation in his parents' apartment when suddenly he tackled her: ". . . he put all his weight on me, and he tried to kiss me and he put his hands on my breasts and up my dress."

title: 2 Bronx Men Are Charged With Murder In Death of 4
description: Two Bronx men were arrested yesterday and charged with the execution-style murders of two children and two women in a Brooklyn apartment Saturday night, the police said.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY T.A. WEIGHS PLAN FOR $1.30 FARE

title: Registry of AIDS-Virus Carriers Is Begun
description: The New Jersey Health Department has quietly established rules requiring that those who test positive for the AIDS virus be identified and that their names and addresses be reported to a central registry. But those who want to remain anonymous may still be tested at 17 state-designated centers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Pop Life
description: Linda Ronstadt's Songs

title: A Men's Fragrance Responds to the Winds of Change
description: THOUGH it is often overshadowed by its better-publicized rivals, Drakkar Noir is one of the country's best-selling men's fragrances. Still, in response to rising competition and rapidly changing consumer attitudes, its maker is overhauling the brand's advertising.

title: Pay-Per-View Pushes a Title Contest
description: The Home Shopping Network, best known for hawking cubic-zirconium rings on cable television, is now trying to sell another product: a pay-per-view college football national championship game.

title: Sports of The Times; The Mets' $29 Million Investment
description: NOW that Bobby Bonilla is baseball's highest-salaried player with a five-year, $29 million Mets contract, the question is: can he possibly be worth the investment?

title: Tulane Names Teevens To Head Coach Position
description: The resume was to Tulane's liking: BUDDY TEEVENS had revived floundering programs at the University of Maine and at Dartmouth. So yesterday he was hired to replace GREG DAVIS, who had resigned as head coach at Tulane after his team won only one game this season and only 14 in Davis's four years. Teevens, 35 years old, guided Dartmouth to consecutive Ivy League championships the last two seasons, taking a team that went 2-8 record in 1987 to a 7-2-1 finish this season. He led Maine to two winning seasons -- 6-5 in 1985 and 7-4 in 1986 -- the first back-to-back winning seasons in 21 years. (AP)

title: Bronx Slaying Is Linked to 2-Year-Old Trail of Violence
description: A fatal shooting at the Bronx home of a murder witness early Monday has been linked to a web of deadly violence growing out of a fight over a girl in an armory party two years ago, investigators said yesterday.

title: Baby's Nanny Set Fatal Fire, Police Charge
description: A 20-year-old woman from Switzerland was charged today with murder and arson in the death of the 3-month-old girl she had been hired to care for.

title: Where, Oh Where, Have All the Fans Gone?
description: Through the 1970's and much of the 1980's, attendance figures for Ranger games at Madison Square Garden were pretty predictable: always around 17,500, a near-capacity crowd.

title: Kenyan Leader Explains Reversal to Party
description: President Daniel arap Moi reversed nine years of national credo today, delivering two speeches to members of his ruling party explaining his decision to allow multiparty politics in this East African nation.

title: Percy Max Apfelbaum, Professor, 90
description: Percy Max Apfelbaum, who retired as a professor of organic chemistry in 1966 after a 42-year teaching career at City College of New York, died last Wednesday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Few Seem to Notice 'E.T.' Precedent
description: In one of the least noticed precedents in recent television history, a familiar scatological term appeared for the first time in a network entertainment program on Thanksgiving night, and in a most unexpected place: the movie "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial."

title: The Tuberculosis Counterattack
description: New York's tuberculosis epidemic poses immediate threats to public health and public finances. It can be effectively met with familiar public health practices; expanding them on the necessary scale requires a coordinated response from Albany and City Hall.

title: Doctor in Abortion Case Is Absent From a Hearing
description: The Manhattan doctor accused of severing the arm of a fetus during an attempted illegal abortion did not show up yesterday for the first day of hearings on whether his medical license should be revoked.

title: 'Pit Bull' at the White House Falls Victim to His Own Role
description: No one expected John Sununu to go gently. And he didn't.

title: Stocks Mostly Up, but Dow Is Off a Bit as Blue Chips Lag
description: Stocks ended yesterday's session mostly higher in narrow trading, but blue chips lagged behind the rest of the market, as the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 5.82 points, to 2,929.56.

title:
Real Estate;
New York Fed's Office Building Rises in the Meadowlands
description: AT a time when commercial real estate development has just about halted in the Northeast, construction is proceeding on an office building for the New York Federal Reserve Bank on the edge of the Meadowlands region here.

title: Publishing Group Sold
description: Patricof & Company Ventures Inc. said it had sold Parenting Unlimited Inc., publisher of a group of magazines, to Time Warner Inc.'s Time Publishing Venture unit. Terms were not disclosed. Parenting Unlimited publishes Baby Talk; Baby on the Way; Basics, and Get Ready for Baby.

title: Maxwell Empire Is Near Collapse As Son Discloses Far Higher Debts
description: The publishing empire of the late Robert Maxwell seemed on the brink of collapse today as one of his sons disclosed that the debts of its private family-owned businesses were far greater than previously estimated, raising the prospect that the family would lose control of its vast holdings.

title: Seminoles Can't Cope With Orangemen
description: Jim Boeheim has been called a lot of things during his 15-year career as Syracuse's head basketball coach. Miracle worker has not been one of them, but it's beginning to look as though it should be.

title: Topics of The Times; Insuring Charities, Piecemeal
description: When Freedom National Bank of Harlem and Community National Bank on Staten Island went bankrupt, some nonprofit institutions were caught short. Confused by the complex rules governing deposit insurance, they had set up multiple accounts in the mistaken belief that each would be insured up to $100,000. They weren't. The nonprofits saw millions of dollars disappear, along with the charitable programs the money made possible.

title: As the Ruble Plummets, Hard Currency Is King
description: For a measure of the madness bedeviling Soviet consumers and business in the twilight of Communism, consider the Soviet ruble.

title: The 'Lemmies' Honor Dubious Achievement
description: It was not exactly with modesty that many of yesterday's winners of the seventh annual Harlan Page Hubbard Lemon Awards said they would rather not have won such an honor.

title: Kimberly, Times Sell Mill Operation
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company completed the sale of the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, their former joint venture based in the northern Ontario town of Kapuskasing. The Spruce Falls power plant on the Mattagami River about 50 miles from Kapuskasing was sold to Ontario Hydro, the state-owned public utility, for approximately $125 million, netting the two companies about $93 million after taxes.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories Inc., Abbott, Ill., a maker of health care products, will acquire Sequoia-Turner Corp., Mountain View, Calif., a maker of instruments for hospitals and laboratories. Terms were not disclosed. * Ashland Exploration Inc., Houston, a subsidiary of Ashland Oil Inc., reached an agreement in principle with Onarep, the national oil company of Morocco, to explore for oil on approximately 1.3 million acres off the shore of Agadir, Morocco.

title: Gumbel Signs New 'Today' Contract
description: Bryant Gumbel signed a new three-year contract yesterday to remain as anchor of the NBC News program "Today."

title: Ban on Race-Exclusive Scholarships Is Expected
description: After a seven-month review, Education Secretary Lamar Alexander is expected to issue regulations on Wednesday that ban race-exclusive scholarships for college students, Administration officials said.

title: Court Clears Sale Of Cetus Division
description: The vice chancellor of the Delaware Chancery Court said she would not block the proposed sale of a division of the Cetus Corporation to Hoffman-LaRoche Inc. if Hoffman-LaRoche agreed to abide by pending arbitration.

title: Independent Ukraine Keeps Sight of Cooperation
description: The backyard roosters glared and crowed proud as ever this morning but seemed no match for the residents of this dirt-road hamlet as they took stock of the stirring new notion of an independent Ukraine being recognized as such by other nations.

title: Tapping the Young for Messages to Their Peers
description: By blending the conventional wisdom of advertising executives with the creative impulses of young minds, a Boston-based advertising agency has generated award-winning public interest advertisements that have been appearing this fall.

title: G.M. to Recall 830,000 Cars to Replace Seat Belts
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would recall all the 830,000 compact Chevrolet Corsicas and Berettas built from 1988 to 1990 to replace seat-belt parts that could break, preventing the driver's or front passenger's shoulder harness from retracting in an accident.

title:
AMERICAN and JAPAN: 50 years later;
Three Myths About Pearl Harbor
description: What didn't happen at Pearl Harbor?

title: Cuomo Seems Closer to Decision on Running for President
description: Although classically cryptic, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo seemed to be accelerating toward a decision today on entering the Presidential race as he backed away from the notion that he needed a state budget solution to run. He said he would like to compete in the New Hampshire primary but would not have to. And he cast himself as an underdog despite polls that show him as the front-runner among Democratic contenders.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Nelson Mandela's visit to New York City referred incorrectly to the security agents with him. They were from the State Department, not the Secret Service.

title: INSIDE
description: Fewer Mothers Married

title: Fee Proposal Attacked at a Landmarks Hearing
description: Rather than cut 10 more employees from its already depleted staff, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has proposed raising $300,000 by imposing work-permit fees for the first time in its history.

title: Chief U.S. Economist Forecasts a Recovery in Spring
description: In what could be a preview of the Bush Administration's testimony to Congress about the economy later this week, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers acknowledged today that the economy was worse than he had expected early this year, but he said he foresaw improvement by spring.

title: Prison for Huey Newton Killer
description: A 27-year-old man was sentenced today to 32 years in prison for killing Huey P. Newton, co-founder of the Black Panther Party. The body of Mr. Newton, 47, shot three times in the head, was found Aug. 22, 1989, in an impoverished Oakland neighborhood known for drug dealing. The defendant, Tyrone Robinson, said he had shot Mr. Newton in self-defense, but prosecutors contended that he had wanted to bolster his standing with a prison gang.

title: Raising the Stakes For New York Wine
description: WITH a little imagination, a visitor standing in front of Millbrook Vineyards' Dutch barn-style winery can see over the undulating Dutchess County hills and across the Hudson River to the spot where French Huguenots planted the region's first vines in 1677.

title: In Arctic, Warm Reunion Ends Cold War Division
description: Last August, six wooden boats carrying residents of Uelen, at the northeastern tip of the Chukchi Peninsula in the Soviet Far East, sailed across the Bering Sea into this northwestern Alaskan port that is home to about 2,700 Eskimos.

title: Memorial for Irving Bieber
description: A memorial for Dr. Irving Bieber, a psychoanalyst and professor who died on Aug. 27 at the age of 80, will be on Friday at 5:30 P.M. at the New York Marriott East Side Hotel at Lexington Avenue and 49th Street in Manhattan.

title: Turmoil for Maxwell Means Anxiety at the Daily News
description: Kevin Maxwell sent word yesterday to employees of The Daily News that the paper, which is owned directly by the Maxwell family, would not be affected by his decision to resign as chairman of the Maxwell Communication Corporation.

title: The President's Man
description: John Sununu's resignation as White House chief of staff may swiftly improve President Bush's image and tattered relations with Congress. It could even help his urgent effort to be seen as more sensitive to domestic needs. But if he wishes now to be understood as changing policy, he'll have to do more than change his chief of staff.

title: Goodrich Is Shutting 3 Vinyl Resin Plants
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company, citing adverse economic conditions, said yesterday that it planned to shut three plants that make vinyl resin, resulting in the layoffs of about 225 workers and a $117.8 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings.

title: High Interest Holds Up House of Credit Cards; Plastic Withdrawal
description: To the Editor:

title: CITES FEAR OF HURTING BUSH
description: John H. Sununu resigned today as the White House chief of staff, telling President Bush that he feared he would be "a drag" on the President's re-election campaign after months of bruising political attacks in which he had become the symbol of the increasing disarray in Mr. Bush's domestic policy team.

title: Book Notes; Summit May Fold As Dismissed Founder Moves to Little, Brown
description: James H. Silberman, who was abruptly removed last month as president and editor in chief of Simon & Schuster's Summit Books division, will join Little, Brown & Company as a vice president and senior editor.

title: Smith Accuser Was 'Very Shook Up' After Incident, Her Friend Testifies
description: The woman who has accused William K. Smith of raping her last March was "hysterical" and "very shook up" immediately after the incident, the friend whom she summoned to the Kennedy estate told a Florida jury yesterday.

title: Jerome J. Donovan, Executive, 51
description: Jerome J. Donovan, a regional executive of Merrill Lynch & Company offices in New Jersey and New York, died on Saturday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 51 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18 ANOTHER U.S. HOSTAGE IS FREED

title: Jets' Young Looking Forward To Getting Back Into Action
description: It doesn't matter to Lonnie Young that the Jets' playoff hopes got dimmer with their 24-13 loss to the Buffalo Bills on Sunday.

title: Mandela, at U.N., Urges Phased End to Sanctions
description: Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, said today that the remaining international sanctions against South Africa should be relaxed in three phases linked to a political process ending white rule.

title: NCNB Plans a Quick Sale of Bad Loans
description: The NCNB Corporation is planning for rapid sales of bad loans after its year-end merger with the C&S/Sovran Corporation, and has promised to concentrate on improving profits of its existing businesses rather than continuing the rapid expansion of the last decade.

title: Kellogg Stock Split
description: The Kellogg Company said shareholders had approved an increase in the number of authorized common shares to 330 million, from 165 million. The move clears the way for a 2-for-1 stock split, payable to holders of record as of Dec. 4. Each share of Kellogg stock will be worth two shares as of Wednesday. Kellogg's shares ended the day up $2.25, to $112.125, on the Big Board.

title: Pan Am Loses Aid From Delta
description: Pan American World Airways may be forced to stop flying as early as today because a financing agreement with Delta Air Lines has collapsed, it was disclosed in bankruptcy court yesterday.

title: NEW PLAN ORDERED ON HAITIAN EXODUS
description: In a ruling that maintains a temporary ban on the forced repatriation of Haitians fleeing their country, a Federal District Court in Miami tonight ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to devise new procedures to screen refugees and assure that no Haitians with a legitimate fear of persecution are sent back.

title: Just the Ticket For Armchair Trips
description: IF cookbooks are anything to go by, Americans are almost insatiably curious about the foods and food ways of other parts of the world. Maybe the motley of American ethnic backgrounds is responsible for the appeal of other places, or maybe it's just dissatisfaction with the familiar and a longing for something exotic to spice up these dreary times. Certainly it's a lot cheaper, often a lot more satisfying, too, to settle down for some armchair travel with one or more of the current crop of books -- as long as the armchair is conveniently set next to a stove so you can try out a recipe or two.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Vice President DAN QUAYLE, whose obfuscations have made news in the past, has received a Golden Bull award from a British organization, the Plain English Campaign, for what it deemed an incomprehensible remark.

title: French Bank in Russia
description: The French bank Credit Lyonnais said today that it had set up a Russian subsidiary to be called Credit Lyonnais Russie. It said that the first branch would be opened in St. Petersburg, where Credit Lyonnais had a branch between 1878 and 1917.

title: High Interest Holds Up House of Credit Cards; Curbing Usury
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernard M. Halbstein, A Surgeon, Dies at 81
description: Dr. Bernard M. Halbstein, an orthopedic surgeon, died last Wednesday at the home of his daughter in Oceanport, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Interlaken, N.J.

title: Champagne Suit Is Settled
description: A WINERY in the Finger Lakes region of New York, sued by 11 Champagne producers, has agreed to stop using the name Chateau de Rheims on its sparkling wine and to refrain from using the name of any French city or geographical area on its products.

title: Madeleine Martin, Artist, 69
description: Madeleine Martin, an artist and founder of the Peter and Madeleine Martin Foundation for the Creative Arts, died on Saturday in San Francisco. She was 69 years old and had homes in San Francisco and Fair Harbor, L.I.

title: Economic Scene; Radio Waves Can Be Solid Gold
description: WANT to earn big money in your spare time? You might take a flier on a sure-fire cold fusion stock recommended by that nice young broker on the telephone from Fort Lauderdale. Or you could really strike it rich by doing what hundreds of lucky millionaires have done: enter one of Washington's bizarre lotteries for licenses to use the airwaves.

title: For One Brooklyn Gang, Restoration Is the Cause
description: PETER ROMEO took his daughter to the carousel in Prospect Park one sunny day last summer. He noticed an old building nearby. It was the Lefferts Homestead, a 200-year-old house that combines Dutch Colonial and Federal details to quite pleasing effect. Too bad the architectural treasure was falling apart.

title: The Keating Shuffle
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Over Warhol's Death to Begin Today
description: Nearly five years after Andy Warhol died in New York Hospital, the survivors and estate of the 58-year-old Pop artist will argue today in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that his death was wrongful and caused by a series of medical mistakes that were covered up by the hospital.

title: A Report Finds Many Students Not Immunized
description: Many children who entered the New York City school system this year have not been tested for tuberculosis or inoculated against other diseases because of problems in a city program that gives medical examinations to students, the city's Comptroller's office said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Calvin Klein Cosmetics Co., New York, a unit of Unilever United States Inc., the Unilever Group's holding company for businesses in the United States, named Suzanne Cassano vice president of marketing. * Merck & Co., Rahway, N.J., named Gerald S. Levey, M.D., senior vice president-medical and scientific affairs of its human health division.

title:
THE LAST U.S. HOSTAGE;
Doctors Say Blows to Head Left 2 Captives Physically Scarred
description: American military physicians concluded today that both Alann Steen and Joseph J. Cicippio would remain physically scarred for life as a result of the blows to the head they suffered at the hands of the captors who took and held them hostage in Lebanon.

title: On the 8th Day of Hanukkah, Children Will Give
description: LIGHT the Hanukkah candles and bring out the presents for the children.

title: CHRONICLE
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH II will bestow a knighthood on Secretary General JAVIER PEREZ DE CUELLAR of the United Nations in recognition of his international achievements, the British Mission to the United Nations has announced.

title: Bankruptcy Seen for Maxwell Companies
description: A top adviser to the Maxwell family's publishing empire said today that the family was preparing to put its collection of private companies into the British equivalent of bankruptcy.

title: Error Exaggerates Wages
description: As it unveiled its major revision of data on the growth of the economy yesterday, the Commerce Department tripped up, making errors in some of the figures it released.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum on Oct. 25 misidentified the law degree he earned at Ohio State University. A reader's letter dated Nov. 20 points out that Mr. Metzenbaum earned an LL.B., not an LL.D.

title: Keating Convicted Of Securities Fraud In S.& L.'s Collapse
description: Charles H. Keating Jr., the Phoenix financier who has come to embody the troubles that decimated the savings and loan industry, was convicted today of securities fraud in connection with the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: The Hostage Lesson, Even Now
description: President Reagan had just started his second term. The buzz in Congress on March 16, 1985, was about Star Wars, MX missiles and the forced resignation of Secretary of Labor Raymond Donovan. That same day Terry Anderson was kidnapped in Beirut. Now Mr. Anderson, the last American hostage, is rubbing his eyes in a strange new world in which blocs and walls have collapsed and even the Middle East is talking peace.

title: Corning Dividend
description: Corning Inc. said its directors had increased the quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share, from 25 cents, and had declared a year-end special dividend of 30 cents a share. The dividends are payable on Dec. 31 to shareholders of record on Dec. 16. Corning directors also approved a 2-for-1 stock split, payable as a 100 percent stock dividend on Feb. 10 to holders of record on Jan. 13. The split will raise the number of outstanding common shares to 193.6 million, from 96.8 million. Corning's shares rose 12.5 cents each today, to $77.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Soviets Postpone Some Payments to Foreign Banks
description: The Soviet Union told commercial banks it owes money to today that, effective Thursday, it is postponing the repayment of principal on all loans made before Jan. 1, 1991.

title: Corrections
description: A sentence in a Nov. 21 letter on Africa by P. P. Lakshman appeared incorrectly because of the typographical error of "not" for "now." The sentence should have read: "It is ironic that Africans, who were the victims of colonialism and slavery by former European despots, are now seen as perpetrators of despotism."

title: Dodgers Put on Big Rush To Secure 2 Top Pitchers
description: In 15 minutes, the Los Angeles Dodgers solved their starting pitching shortage. The Mets should be so efficient.

title: Chairman of Guinness Will Retire Next Year
description: Guinness P.L.C., Britain's sixth-largest company, announced yesterday that Anthony Tennant would retire as chairman and chief executive at the end of 1992 and be replaced by Tony Greener, the group's managing director.

title: Sports of The Times; Business Disguised As a Game
description: SOMEONE asked Lou Carnesecca the other day if he liked the Big East-Atlantic Coast Conference Challenge.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "You do what you have to. You wake up every day, summon up the energy from somewhere. You think you haven't got it and you get through the day and you do it. Day after day after day." -- TERRY A. ANDERSON, explaining how he got through his ordeal. [ A20:5. ]

title: An Artist's Joyous Gifts To Herself
description: AT the age of 85, Eva Zeisel could easily rest on her laurels. One of the most prolific ceramists of the 1940's and 50's, she designed countless sets of sleek, joyous, mass-produced china for dozens of major manufacturers. Occupied with writing and teaching since the mid-60's, she has now returned to product design, this time in wood. Her new line of 19 accessories in poplar, cherry, walnut and mahogany includes candlesticks and lamps.

title: M.G.A. Honors Beard
description: ANN BEARD of Essex Fells, N.J., the chairwoman of the United States Golf Association Women's Committee, was honored with the Metropolitan Golf Association's Distinguished Service Award last night. JOHN BALDWIN of the Meadow Brook Club on Long Island received his second consecutive M.G.A. player-of-the-year award.

title: Carolco Cuts Staff by 25% And May Scale Back Films
description: It made the biggest hit movie of the year, "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," and it is pressing ahead with other expensive films, including "Basic Instinct," a thriller starring Michael Douglas. But Carolco Pictures Inc. is being buffeted by the same problems that killed most of Hollywood's smaller production companies in recent years.

title: Review/Theater; An Early 30-Year Black Struggle
description: "Zion," Beverly Trader's epic play with music by the New Federal Theater, depicts the 30-year struggle of parishioners in Marietta, Ga., to establish one of the earliest black churches in the United States. The play, a sprawling hybrid of historical drama and gospel pageantry, begins in 1836 and spans the Civil War. Although it embraces a lot more material than it can comfortably assimilate, it still conveys a pungent sense of history's wheels grinding painfully forward.

title: School Administrators Aren't All Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Running for President: Hate and Fear
description: It's no surprise that the former Nazi and Ku Klux Klansman David Duke is running for President. Mr. Duke is a professional candidate. He made a living that way for nearly 15 years, until 1988, when he was elected to Louisiana's legislature by the narrowest of margins.

title: Unregistered Aliens Have Right to School
description: To the Editor:

title: Bagging a 10,000-Pound Twig House in the Wilds of Maine
description: THE old adage says, "Never shop when depressed."

title: The Gold Doesn't Shine: Untraditional Jewelry
description: Glitter is not to be found at "Things to Come: Jewelry Designs for the Future," a show featuring the work of 15 designers that opened yesterday at the Aaron Faber Gallery in Manhattan. Instead, there are pieces made of rubber and touch fasteners, of metal oxidized and shaped to look like leaves, and of matte, rather than shiny, gold.

title: Bert T. Combs, 80, Dies in Flood; Was Kentucky Governor in 60's
description: Former Gov. Bert T. Combs of Kentucky, a Democrat who championed fiscal reforms and civil rights in his four-year tenure as the state's chief executive three decades ago, was found dead in a river in east-central Kentucky yesterday after his car was swept away by floodwaters. He was 80 years old.

title: When Casey Could Have Met Iranians in '80; Suspicious Timing
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Natural Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: So where does that leave the organizers of the dinner-dance, which is to be attended by 900 people at the Winter Garden in the World Financial Center? The highlight of the evening was to have been the entry of Miss Taylor carrying a mask called "Lachrymosa," designed by HENRY DUNAY and valued at $2 million. It is studded with 936 diamonds, weighing 135 carats or so altogether.

title: Tickets Honored By Some
description: Delta Air Lines, USAir and Continental Airlines yesterday offered to honor most tickets issued by Pan American World Airways, whose 64 years of aviation history ended in turmoil. But the offers are for a limited time and contain an array of restrictions.

title: Next for Jets' Once-Stingy Defense Is Lions' Hard-Running Sanders
description: Until last Sunday, when they gave up 124 yards on the ground to Buffalo's Thurman Thomas, the leading rusher in the National Football League, the Jets had not allowed any runner to post a 100-yard game against them.

title: Genesis Health Ventures reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge which reflects early retirement of debt of $ 311,000 for the latest year and $ 81,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Castro, in Talk With U.S. Senator, Calls Fuel Crisis 'the Biggest Test'
description: President Fidel Castro told a visiting United States Senator this week that Cuba was struggling with a fuel and energy crisis that he regarded as "the biggest test of the survival of our revolution."

title: Events: Benefit Auction Of Miniature Rooms
description: Small Ideas Christie's New York, 502 Park Avenue (59th Street); (212) 893-8600.

title: Handley Makes Team Pride The Priority Over the Playoffs
description: For the Giants, it has come to this: Coach Ray Handley said today that the defending Super Bowl champions were playing this week mainly to restore pride.

title: Americans Will Sing in a Generation or So
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Fails in Move to Ease Budget Cuts
description: A day after threatening to curtail enrollment at seven community colleges because of city budget cuts, the Chancellor of the City University met with Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday but failed to persuade him to restore the $5.6 million in funds.

title: Power of the Yen Winning Asia New 'Co-Prosperity' Is Displacing U.S.
description: The day that most Americans remember as a day of infamy resonates very differently in Asia. Here, Pearl Harbor is regarded as a sideshow to Japan's real ambitions in World War II -- the creation of a "Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere," an economic and military empire that stretched from the coal mines of Manchuria to the oilfields of Indonesia.

title: Vintage McKim, Mead & White
description: THE last period room that the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art can accommodate does not sound impressive: a vestibule and a staircase to nowhere. But Peter Kenny, an assistant curator of American decorative arts, calls the 1884 oak-lined passageway "a really amazing early example of McKim, Mead & White" as well as "a succinct style statement."

title: From Iran to U.S., a Hint of Good Will
description: The release of Terry Anderson closes a painful, eight-year chapter of America's experience with hostage taking in Lebanon and removes the most serious obstacle to an improvement in the relationship between Washington and Teheran.

title: Review/Dance; Spanish Traditions, but With Individualism
description: The Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company, which opened on Tuesday night for two weeks at the Joyce Theater, takes a creative approach to dance idioms, especially flamenco, that other Spanish troupes treat more straightforwardly.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- Addenda; Employees Return To Foote, Cone
description: The twenty employees who left Foote, Cone & Belding Direct last week to start their own direct-marketing shop returned yesterday after legal action was taken against them.

title: ANDERSON, LAST U.S. HOSTAGE, IS FREED BY CAPTORS IN BEIRUT
description: Terry A. Anderson, the last American and longest-held hostage in Lebanon, was set free tonight by his kidnappers after nearly seven years in captivity.

title: Review/Music; Of Grace and Grandiosity
description: Both Haydn and Liszt had strong physical ties to Hungary and an even stronger cosmopolitan bent, but there the similarities mostly end. Musically, they make an odd couple, Haydn with his self-effacing grace and wry wit, Liszt with his preening grandiosity and ponderous proclamatory tone. But the pianist Alfred Brendel is fond of both composers, and on Friday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art he split his recital between them.

title: Theater Ads to Say if Play Has Officially Opened
description: Representatives of Broadway and Off Broadway producers reached agreement yesterday with the city's Department of Consumer Affairs in a controversy over whether advertisements should label as previews shows that have not officially opened.

title: Study Set on Abortion Pill's Use in Breast Cancer
description: The French producer of the abortion pill RU486 will begin a large-scale study of the pill's potency in treating breast cancer next year in Canada, officials of the company said today.

title: Old Veterans Return to Mark a Day of Infamy
description: They are coming back to remember Pearl Harbor again.

title: Foreman Is the People's Choice
description: Up on the second floor of the Eldorado Hotel Casino here, just outside the convention center in which George Foreman trains daily, there is a life-sized photo of Foreman and an opponent fighting at close quarters.

title: Gun Makers and Dealers Should Face Penalties
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Nation; A Predictable Demise
description: John Sununu gave up the struggle to stay on as White House chief of staff more quickly than Sherman Adams did during the Eisenhower Administration. Both formerly were New Hampshire Governors, both regarded themselves as indispensable to Presidents who almost agreed, and both were disliked if not despised by the rest of Washington.

title: Northrop Loses Korea Suit
description: A civil court in Seoul today rejected a $6.5 million lawsuit filed by the Northrop Corporation against the family of a former Government official who acted as a sales agent for the United States aircraft maker.

title: Police Seeking Motive in Baby's Death
description: The parents whose infant died in a fire that investigators said was started by a Swiss child-care worker told the police that they had noticed nothing unusual about the young woman's behavior in the five weeks since she arrived from Switzerland.

title: Review/Theater; After Ceausescu, Another Kind of Terror
description: Three months after the 1989 fall of the Ceausescus, a theatrical brigade including the British playwright Caryl Churchill, a director named Mark Wing-Davey and 10 of Mr. Wing-Davey's acting students went to Romania on what promised to be a preposterous mission. Their aim was to become instant experts on a nation in post-revolutionary turmoil and to make a play about what they had seen. Their visit was scarcely longer than a week.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Arlo Guthrie Carnegie Hall

title: Lixor Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Its Cash Depleted, Pan Am Shuts
description: Pan American World Airways finally died yesterday -- broke and too weak to attempt yet another comeback -- two days after Delta Air Lines ended its financing arrangement.

title: For Disabled Women, A Time For Sharing
description: Each Saturday and Sunday in an auditorium at the Y.W.C.A. on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, the Networking Project for Disabled Women and Girls brings together the two groups so that they can learn from each other.

title: Nylund Needs Surgery
description: GARY NYLUND, the Islanders' veteran defenseman, needs new surgery on his left heel and will be out for two to three more months, the team announced yesterday.

title: Credibility of Chief Witness Is Debated in Closing Arguments of Miller Fraud Case
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, one of New York State's most influential legislators, was an active participant in fraudulent schemes to buy and sell cooperative apartments, a prosecutor charged yesterday in his summation.

title: Thoughts From The Glass Booth
description: Dr. Manuel A. Gilman has watched nearly 19,000 horse races as one of the three stewards who monitor New York racing from a glassed-in booth high over the finish line. But as he closes out as career that included 37 years as a veterinarian and 7 as a steward, the view that troubles him most is the Offtrack Betting parlor across the street from the race track.

title: Books of The Times; Mice, Parrots, Hippos, And Children, Too
description: "Children are entitled to their otherness, as anyone is," wrote Alastair Reid in "Places, Poems, Preoccupations" (1963), "and when we reach them, as we sometimes do, it is generally on a point of sheer delight, to us so astonishing, but to them so natural." With the idea of furthering such contact, here are 10 delightful children's picture books that one hopes will seem both astonishing and natural. They are described in roughly ascending order of sophistication.

title: Newport Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses incurred by Micro-Controle's six non-French units, which reduced results by about 4 cents a share.The latest quarter's sales included sales of the non-French Micro-Controle units that were purchased June 28, 1991.

title: Texas Medical School Gets 4 Gifts Totaling $85 Million
description: Four private gifts amounting to $85 million were announced today by the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center here, including three donations of $25 million or more each that are considered to be among the largest ever made to a public university.

title: Free At Last
description: On March 16, 1985, Terry A. Anderson was snatched off the streets of Beirut. For more than six years years, he struggled to survive in an underworld of terror few can imagine. Terry is now free. For the first time in too many years, he is inhaling air that is not tinted an eerie twilight blue and funky with the smell of bodies and human waste.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: EACH December, Frank Gresham's two daughters provide him with a measure of the time left until Christmas that's as accurate as any calendar. The ritual begins when the girls, now 9 and 10 years old, hand him a few sheets of paper.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22 LAST U.S. HOSTAGE IS FREE

title: INSIDE
description: False Start for Mideast Talks

title: National Beverage Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 577,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 950,000, or 41 cents a share, for the 6 months, which represents equity in the earnings of its Burnup & Sims Inc. affiliate.

title: With Americans Free, Former Hostages Tell of Endurance and Resistance
description: The Americans who had been held hostage in Lebanon started to tell their stories yesterday, pouring out a torrent of details that ranged from how they coped with the starchy food to how they endured conditions harsher than had previously been known.

title: Improving a Table's Fancy Footwork
description: If you imagine the top of a busy dining table to be the longest-suffering of all furniture surfaces, then get down on all fours and witness what fidgety diners have done to table legs over the years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There's always something to worry about on the frenzied New York social circuit, and for two days concern has been focused on ELIZABETH TAYLOR and her health. Miss Taylor has had to cancel her appearance tonight at the annual masquerade dinner-dance of the American Foundation for AIDS Research because she has the flu and a fever hovering around 103, and has been told to stay home in Los Angeles.

title: Gun That Was Found on Defendant Is Linked to Kahane Shooting
description: Police ballistics experts yesterday linked both the killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane and the shooting minutes later of a Postal Service police officer to the silver-plated gun found with the accused assassin, El Sayyid A. Nosair.

title: Limits Proposed for Race-Based Scholarships
description: Education Secretary Lamar Alexander proposed rules today that would ban scholarships based exclusively on race except under specific circumstances.

title: Job Cuts at Bass
description: Bass P.L.C. said it would cut a total of 460 jobs as part of the restructuring of its British brewing operations. Bass has incurred an exceptional charge totaling $:55 million, or about $98 million, in its fiscal 1991 earnings because of the restructuring and job losses at its Bass Taverns unit. Bass said the revamping would take place over two and a half years. The job losses will be partly offset by 50 new jobs at Bass's Cape Hill Brewery in Birmingham, where the company plans to invest $:50 million by 1994. Bass is transferring some brewing and packaging operations to Cape Hill from a brewery in Glasgow.

title: Review/Film; Homage to a Partnership In Life and in the Arts
description: Among the tributes expressed in Elliot Caplan's beautifully filmed homage to the composer John Cage and the choreographer and dancer Merce Cunningham, the most sweeping comes from the poet and potter M. C. Richards.

title: George F. Harkins, 78, Leader in Lutheranism
description: The Rev. George F. Harkins, a leader in American Lutheranism, died on Tuesday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Wyckoff, N.J.

title: Rebuilding the Building of Castles in the Sand in Casino Land
description: "It's the second oldest profession in Atlantic City," says Ralph Halpslader, who just a few months ago joined a new wave of sand sculptors in this storied resort city.

title: Critic's Notebook; For TV, It's a Little Bit of Everything
description: It's "Dallas." It's "Perry Mason." It's "Rashomon." With the Palm Beach partyland ambience, the Kennedy name and faces, the dramatic opening testimony of the woman known to television audiences as "the alleged victim," the trial of William K. Smith is proving to be a television spectacular.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Maurice John Vaughan Chicago Blues 73 Eighth Avenue, at 13th Street Manhattan Through tonight

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Errol Parker Drummer S.O.B.'s

title: Added Cuts Are Planned By Du Pont
description: The Du Pont Company, hoping to make a substantial gain in profits, is planning a new round of belt tightening and productivity improvements, company officials said yesterday.

title: Camps Can Smooth Trail Route
description: Andy Boyland's idea of a great ski vacation is five days of lectures, morning exercises, races, videotape analysis and strategy that concentrate on finding the fastest line through the course. Boyland is one of a growing number of skiers who start the season with a week of racing instruction at a ski camp.

title: Seven Oaks International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said it did not record any tax benefit in the 1991 first half, compared with a gain of $ 1,452,000 reported in the year-ago second quarter and $ 2,055,000 in the year-ago 6 months.

title: President of Phibro Is Promoted to Chief
description: Salomon Inc.'s Phibro Energy unit announced yesterday that Andrew J. Hall, its president, would succeed Ernst Weil as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Weil, who is 62 years old, retires on Dec. 31.

title: E. J. de Margerie, Former Ambassador From France to U.S.
description: Emmanuel Jacquin de Margerie, a former French Ambassador to the United States and national museum administrator, died on Monday in Paris. He was 66 years old.

title: Flow International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 49,000 in the quarter and $ 185,000, or 1 cent a share, in the 6 months.c-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 345,000, or 3 cents a share, and $ 780,000, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Thomas Nelson Porter, A Stage Manager, 59
description: Thomas Nelson Porter, a Broadway stage manager, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Freddie Hubbard Quintet Fat Tuesday's 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street Manhattan Through Sunday

title: Changing of the Goal Guard for Devils
description: After starting only once in the first 20 games, Craig Billington is emerging as the premier goaltender for the Devils.

title: Hearings on Economy Opening Today
description: The Congressional hearings on the state of the economy that begin Thursday will spotlight the fundamental difference between Republicans and Democrats over tax policy and what makes the economy tick.

title: Howard Activated For Giants Practice
description: The Giants added Erik Howard to the practice roster today, and the Pro Bowl nose tackle took part in his first practice since back surgery 10 weeks ago.

title: Economy Expands Sluggishly
description: The Government reported today that the economy grew at a 1.7 percent annual rate during the quarter that ended in September, an advance considerably less than initially estimated and a disappointment to both private analysts and the Bush Administration.

title: Joffrey Won't Play New York in Spring
description: The Joffrey Ballet has canceled its spring season at City Center, its New York base, in what Robert Yesselman, the company's executive director, described yesterday as a move toward fiscal stabilization.

title: Campuses, Artful and Otherwise
description: IN the finicky eye of Thomas A. Gaines, the author of "The Campus as a Work of Art" (Praeger, $45), Amherst College's hillside buildings represent "the last word in missed opportunities." The modernist skyline of the State University of New York campus in Purchase offers "one whammy too many for the harried eye," he writes.

title: White House Memo; Sununu Downfall: He Broke 7 Cardinal Rules
description: The White House is an easy place to lose perspective.

title: Key Rates
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Interstate Bakeries Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 16
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 10,176,000 which is related to the retirement of certain debt.The company said the latest quarter was the first to reflect the full impact of the deleveraging as a result of the initial public offering completed in July.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MASONS know that the beauty of brickwork is only skin deep. To save money where the strength of structural bricks is not needed, they often use facing or veneer bricks, which are thinner and purely decorative. Applying them requires the same skill as structural bricklaying and is beyond most amateurs. But imitation facing brick, sold at home centers, looks almost exactly the same and is easily applied.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advest Bank, Hartford, a unit of the Advest Group, named Charles P. Bassos president and chief executive. * Coventry Corp., Nashville, which operates health maintenance organizations, said Philip Hertik, president and chief operating officer, would assume the additional position of chief executive next May. He will succeed Joseph P. Williams, who will remain chairman. * First Interstate Bank of Texas N.A., Houston, a unit of First Interstate Bancorp, said Linnet F. Deily, president and chief executive, would assume the additional post of chairman. * Fuchs, Cuthrell & Co., New York, an executive placement firm, named Walter R. Trosin vice chairman. * Lincoln National Corp., Fort Wayne, Ind., an insurance holding company, named Robert A. Anker president and chief operating officer of the company and its Lincoln National Life Insurance Co. unit. * Prudential Securities Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Prudential Insurance Co. of America, named A. Laurence Norton Jr. executive vice president.

title: Petrolite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rough Justice for Dr. Baltimore
description: The renowned biologist David Baltimore has paid a harsh but necessary penalty for his efforts to whitewash a case of scientific fraud. A 1986 research paper prepared under his supervision was supported in part by data almost certainly fabricated by a colleague. The controversy over his handling of the affair has forced Dr. Baltimore, a Nobel laureate, to resign as president of Rockefeller University.

title: Essay; Gulf-War Skeleton
description: A trifecta, as those who play the ponies know, is a bet on the order of finish: if you can predict win, place and show, you hit the jackpot.

title: Penn Traffic Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 2,785,000 related to the purchase of subordinated notes in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Included one-time gain of $ 2,200,000 related to the sale of the New England division in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, the Kitchen Bookshelf column in The Living Section yesterday misstated the price of "American Game Cooking" by John Ash and Sid Goldstein (Aris/Addison-Wesley). It is $25.

title: Now It's Yankees' Turn to Make Some Moves
description: While the Mets have clearly wrestled any portion of the spotlight the Yankees still possessed in New York by lavishing $36.5 million upon the free-agent power hitters Eddie Murray and Bobby Bonilla, General Manager Gene Michael of the Yankees is having to use trades rather than huge contracts to solve the team's many problems.

title: Willis, Thomas Fined
description: KEVIN WILLIS of the Atlanta Hawks was fined $3,500 and ISIAH THOMAS of the Detroit Pistons was fined $3,000 by the N.B.A. for an incident during a game last Wednesday night. Thomas was fouled by Willis while driving the lane with 1 minute 59 seconds left and the score tied, 90-90, in the game eventually won by Detroit, 100-91. Willis was called for a flagrant foul and Thomas for a technical foul for retaliating.

title: Shaking Your Booty
description: STEPHEN VISAKAY has lent a chrome cocktail shaker, circa 1930, to the Broadway production of "Nick and Nora," and he hardly misses it. In his Spring Valley, N.Y., home, he has 800 such shakers, and he is selling 50 more in the Nyack, N.Y., shop he runs with his fiancee, Arlene Lederman.

title: Brendle's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Mary M. Phillips, 77, An Editor of Fashion
description: Mary McDonough Phillips, an editor who helped train a generation of fashion journalists, died last Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived in New York City and Jupiter, Fla.

title: Throughout, A.P. Worked For Anderson
description: Over the nearly seven years since Terry A. Anderson was dragged into a car by terrorists in Beirut, obtaining his release was a paramount concern at The Associated Press, where his salary continued to be paid week after week in the determined hope that he would be able to claim it. The A.P.'s partner in this effort was Peggy Say, Mr. Anderson's sister.

title: Duke Takes His Anger Into 1992 Race
description: David Duke, the former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan who polarized Louisiana politics with his angry campaigns against welfare and affirmative action, announced today that he was entering the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Marlins Interest Rose
description: PETE ROSE says he intends to seek reinstatement to baseball next year and that he would be interested in working for the Florida Marlins, one of the two National League expansion teams for 1993.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hard Times Call for the Hard Sell
description: RETAILERS are changing the face they present to shoppers during the holiday season, shifting from the warm and fuzzy image-building long popular at this time of year to hard-selling product promotions.

title: Between First and Second Wives, a Gulf
description: IN this quintessential suburb near Hartford, four women took a respite from their weekend chores one recent Saturday morning to attend a workshop on the increasingly necessary, yet awkward, relationship between the first and second wife of the same man.

title: Burnup & Sims reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Latest share earnings for the quarter and 6 months both included a 7 cents-a-share gain from repurchase of Burnup & Sims 12 percent debentures.Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 6 months both included a 5 cents-a-share gain from the repurchase of Burnup & Sims 12 percent debentures.The company said National Beverage Corp. has a 35 percent stake in Burnup & Sims.

title: Sununu Expects Skinner Will Be New Staff Chief
description: John H. Sununu, the ousted White House chief of staff, said tonight that he expected his successor to be Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner.

title: Stocks Are Mixed as Dow Declines 17.89
description: Stocks closed mixed for the second consecutive day, as blue-chip issues again failed to keep pace with the overall market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 17.89 points to end at 2,911.67.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Dixieland Food Stores Inc., a unit of Fleming Cos., Oklahoma City, a wholesale food distributor, has reached an agreement to sell substantially all of its supermarket operations to Piggly Wiggly Mid-SouthInc., a supermarket operator. No terms were disclosed. * Eastman Chemical Co., Kingsport, Tenn., has formed a venture with Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the French chemical maker, make cellulose acetate. * Genicom Corp., Waynesboro, Va., a maker of computer products, said it had signed a letter to acquire Rastek Corp., an engineering company. Terms were not disclosed. * Rubbermaid Inc., Wooster, Ohio, has reached an agreement to buy Cipsa, a Mexican plastic and rubber housewares maker. The seller is Grupo IRSA S.A. of Mexico. No terms were disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Monday about Bridgeport University misstated the admissions policy of another Connecticut university. Wesleyan, in Middletown, continues to admit students without regard to financial need.

title: ISRAEL A NO-SHOW, SO ARABS DEPART
description: Syrian, Lebanese, Jordanian and Palestinian negotiators gathered at the State Department today for the second round of Middle East peace talks, but they quickly departed after Israeli delegates failed to turn up.

title: New York's Nonresident Tax Rule Is Struck Down
description: An appellate court has struck down a New York law requiring many nonresidents to file joint income-tax returns, but tax officials in New York and New Jersey predicted today that few commuters would benefit from the ruling.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. General information phone: (212) 963-1234 Tours are conducted 9 A.M.-5:45 P.M.

title: Samuel Dawson, 49; Was Defense Lawyer
description: Samuel H. Dawson, a prominent criminal defense lawyer in New York City, died Monday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Mugged Officer's Life Saved by His Necktie
description: A retired New York City police officer who was mugged yesterday in the Wall Street area owes his life to his necktie, the police said.

title: State Sues Potamkin, Citing Tactics in Car Sales
description: The Potamkin group of car dealerships routinely used "bait-and-switch tactics" and other deceptive sales practices, the New York State Attorney General charged in a suit filed yesterday.

title: Killings at a Record Pace as Other Crimes Drop
description: Killings in New York City are running above last year's record pace, despite a drop in other kinds of violent crime, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said yesterday.

title: Ukraine Faces a Familiar Post-Communist Quandary of Money and Politics
description: Nascent self-government was working at cross-purposes today on two important levels of an independent Ukraine, laying bare the post-Communist quandary of how to attract new money and eclipse old politics.

title: EUROPE'S 'POOR 4' DEMAND MORE AID
description: Fearful of being condemned to "poor relative" status, Spain, Greece, Portugal and Ireland are demanding that their richer partners promise them greater aid when European Community leaders meet next week to chart the region's economic and political future.

title: Lag in Cease-Fire in Yugoslavia Hindering U.N. Role, Envoy Says
description: The United Nations envoy, Cyrus R. Vance, said today that a cease-fire had so far failed to take hold in Yugoslavia, hindering the dispatch of a peacekeeping force to end five months of civil war.

title: Talking Deals; Reverse Buyouts Losing Appeal
description: THE market for initial stock offerings by debt-laden private companies appears to have taken a downward turn, leaving some investors and bankers openly wondering whether the opportunity for wild success in those deals has passed.

title: J. I. Case Plans to Cut Work Force by 4,000
description: J. I. Case, the faltering maker of farm and construction equipment, will eliminate 4,000 jobs by the end of next year, paring its work force to about 21,000, its parent, Tenneco Inc., said today.

title: Gun Makers and Dealers Should Face Penalties; Mandatory Sentences
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stock prices were lower in Tokyo today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues lost 210.27 points, or nearly 1 percent, to close at 22,459.17. On Wednesday, the index surged 502.61 points.

title: A Design Archive Sings the Unsung
description: UNTOLD numbers of works by black American designers remain unidentified and unsung. "Unless a picture or a description of the person survives, you would not know," said Ethel W. Williamson, who is organizing the Cooper-Hewitt Museum's African-American Design Archive, which will be a computerized collection of artisans' biographies.

title: J. F. Knott, 55, Chief Of Recycling Company
description: Joseph F. Knott, president and chief operating officer of the Safety-Kleen Corporation of Elgin, Ill., died Monday morning at his home in Oak Brook, Ill., a Chicago suburb. He was 55 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters on Thursday about the folk singer Arlo Guthrie referred incorrectly to the building in Great Barrington, Mass., featured in his song "Alice's Restaurant." He does not own it; he is renting it while trying to raise money to buy it.

title: Grad Students At Yale Strike To Get a Union
description: More than 1,000 Yale University graduate students went on strike today, joined by several thousand of the school's clerical, custodial, food-service and other workers. The strike caused dozens of classes to be canceled or rescheduled, closed student dining halls and disrupted many university offices.

title: Bucks' Harris Resigns
description: DEL HARRIS, in his fifth season as coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, resigned yesterday and was replaced by his top assistant, FRANK HAMBLEN. Harris said he wanted to devote more time to his duties as vice president of basketball operations.

title: Bayou Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,572,000.

title: John C. Miller, 83; Writer and Professor Of American History
description: John C. Miller, a retired professor at Stanford University who wrote several major books about early American history that won praise for their scholarship and analysis, died Sunday at Stanford University Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83 years old and lived in Palo Alto.

title: Care Faulted In the Death Of Warhol
description: Andy Warhol -- anemic, undernourished and fearful of hospitals -- slipped into a coma after surgery and died virtually unattended because his doctors overloaded him with fluids, a lawyer for his estate said yesterday in opening arguments in a wrongful death suit.

title: When Casey Could Have Met Iranians in '80
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: National team titles are very rarely won by players unknown to fame, but it happened during the weekend at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in Indianapolis. In a strong field that included several former world champions, the victor was a squad from Kentucky: Keith Wilson, Gary Peterson, Dennis Hesthaven, Ralph Letizia, John Ambach, all of Louisville, and Benton Wheeler of Lexington.

title: Furon Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit for the settlement of certain terminated pension plans of $ 398,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.The company said in its ongoing efforts to initiate ''world-class performance techniques,'' inventories were reduced, which contributed to a positive free cash flow of $ 2.9 million. The company also said it is in an ''outstanding'' position to take advantage of an upturn in the business cycle.

title: Hunt, Peck and Repairs
description: Midtown Typewriter 124 West 23d Street, New York, N.Y. 10011; (212) 255-4752.

title: Pacificare Health Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Olympian's Dream: On the Road Again
description: By now, it was just another game for Shawn McEachern, another night of checking and skating and packing up the equipment.

title: And Now, a Word From the Tar Heels: Blowout
description: The made-for-television plan was that this game, Seton Hall against North Carolina, would be one of the highlights of the third and final challenge series between the Atlantic Coast Conference and the Big East.

title: Cuomo Advisers Discuss Possible Campaign Aides
description: Three advisers to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today began compiling a list of political professionals who could fill top staff jobs in a Cuomo Presidential campaign. But they said the project was their own initiative, did not have the Governor's formal approval and did not reflect a decision by Mr. Cuomo to run.

title: Vikings Confirm Report That Burns Will Retire
description: The Minnesota Vikings confirmed yesterday that JERRY BURNS would retire as coach after the season. Burns had indicated in recent weeks that he would not return.

title: Justices Weigh Ban on Voicing Hate
description: The Supreme Court wrestled today with what steps the Constitution permits governments to take in efforts to curb speech and acts that express hostility based on race, religion or sex.

title: Digicon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-The provision for income taxes included $ 115,000, equal to 1 cent a share, which is not payable currently or in the future because of the availability of tax benefits in the U.S. and certain foreign countries. In accordance with staff accounting bulletin No. 86, $ 115,000 has been added to the company's paid-in capital account.c-After an extraordinary credit of $ 973,000.

title: Possis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 168,509, or 2 cents a share.c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $ 182,228, or 2 cents a share.

title: Perrier Is Sued by a Rival
description: A Canadian beverage company has filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit accusing Perrier of stealing its unique bottle design and violating trade agreements.

title: LIBYAN MAINTAINS HE HOLDS SUSPECTS
description: The new chief of Libyan intelligence services asserted in an interview published today that he had ordered the detention of two Libyan officials accused by the United States and Britain of carrying out the bombing of a Pan Am airplane in 1988.

title: 4 Held and Linked to 40 Queens Store Robberies
description: After a manhunt that included several stakeouts and air surveillance of a broad swath of Queens, the police have arrested four men and linked them to more than 40 convenience store robberies there since August.

title: Doctor Describes Death of a Girl Who Suffered Botched Abortion
description: A doctor from Kings County Hospital testified yesterday that a 17-year-girl died of infection after a botched abortion that may have involved dirty instruments.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY OLD SCHOOL TIES THAT DO NOT BIND

title: Accuser in Smith Trial Tells of Fear and Rape
description: Choking back tears, the 30-year-old Florida woman who has accused William K. Smith of raping her on the front lawn of the Kennedy compound took the witness stand today and offered her anguished recollections of that night.

title: Bucharest Journal; Critics View Ceausescu Works and, Well, Despair
description: The pompous apartments and sweeping boulevards were meant to mark the dawn of an era, eternal monuments defining the soul of Romania under Nicolae Ceausescu. But now the future of the monstrous buildings is being debated as Romania struggles toward democracy.

title: Despite a Coup, Togo's Reform Prime Minister Clings to Post
description: Togo's reformist Prime Minister was still in his post today despite a coup by rebellious troops, but diplomats said he would have to make big concessions to hard-liners from the former ruling party.

title: Aspirin Linked to Aid in Colon Cancer Fight
description: Aspirin, which is being widely used in low doses to prevent heart attacks and strokes, may also prevent deaths from colon cancer, according to new findings from a large nationwide study.

title: PHP Healthcare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Canada's Reckons With AIDS
description: Across Canada today, players, coaches and fans of professional hockey anxiously struggled to come to terms with the disclosure by two Montreal doctors that a young woman who died of AIDS two years ago contended she had had sex with 30 to 70 National Hockey League players.

title: On L.I., the Anti-Tax Prophets Come In From the Wilderness
description: At Pat Friedman's house, the green-shingled Cape Cod on Roxbury Road South, the one with the tiny lot where the trees are bedecked with blue ribbon, property taxes have been rising, but not without a fight.

title: Diversicare Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Book Writing by Maya Is Put Centuries Earlier
description: A ceramic vessel bearing rows of Maya glyphs and scenes of mythological events has been identified by scholars as the earliest known evidence of book writing in pre-Columbian America.

title: I.B.M. Plans To Detail Plan Today
description: I.B.M. plans to disclose today the first steps it will take on the road to fundamental change in its operations.

title: Toward a 'Family Friendly' Work Place
description: HER weekly calendar is a gridlock of meetings. Some are with parents who utter a familiar lament: If only they had 28 hours in a day, perhaps they might find the energy to handle jobs and raise children at the same time. Others are at corporations seeking ways to ease family stresses so employees can give their all when they are on the job.

title: As Helmick Resigns, His Familiar Rationale Misses the Ethical Point
description: Robert Helmick's resignation early yesterday as a member of the International Olympic Committee completed a spectacular two-month fall that left him stripped of any meaningful role in national or international sports.

title: CBS Adding an Overnight News Program
description: CBS News announced yesterday that it would begin an overnight news program early next year, replacing "Nightwatch," a news interview program that has been broadcast since 1982.

title: Home Video
description: In a CBS News documentary released on videotape today, a former radar operator looks back. Early on the morning of Dec. 7, 1941, he reported a "large indication" of aircraft streaking in from the sea toward Pearl Harbor. No one, he says, was very interested.

title: 'Boys' Film Leaves Studio Wondering
description: Holiday decorations are splashed around the offices of 20th Century Fox, but the studio is probably the gloomiest in town.

title: Survey Finds Vacant Slots In Drug Treatment Centers
description: Despite a chronic shortage of drug treatment programs in New York City, hundreds of treatment slots go unfilled because of a failure to match clients with available services, a new survey has found.

title: Help Russia Now
description: It's strange to be working in an office in the old Communist Party headquarters 20 feet below where Stalin sat. Today this building is occupied by the democratic government of the Russian federal republic, which is preparing the greatest economic reform ever undertaken. But few people in the West seem to realize what is happening.

title: Bob Evans Farms reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
M.T.A. Is Turning to Itself on Fare Increase
description: Unusual forces are pushing transit officials toward a reluctant but inevitable conclusion: If they want to limit the size of the New York City subway and bus fare increase, they must find the money themselves, within the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title:
Market Place;
Allergan Gains From a Reduction
description: IN 1989, when Allergan Inc. was spun off to shareholders from its parent, SmithKline Beckman, now SmithKline Beecham, the company faced some problems. Among them: Allergan's costs were too high, its manufacturing system was inefficient, there were some gaps in new-product development and it was saddled with a heavy load of debt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- Addenda; New Campaigns
description: * DDB Needham Worldwide is promoting itself with print advertisements in Chicago, Los Angeles and New York that showcase a variety of its clients' products as "gift ideas for a merry Christmas." In a memo to agency employees, Keith Reinhard, chairman and chief executive, said the ads symbolize the agency's belief that in a soft economy advertising is "not a discretionary cost to be reduced or eliminated." The ad appears in The New York Times today on pages D12 and D13.

title: Homedco Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 559,000 which reflects unamortized deferred debt costs relating to the refinancing of debt completed June 1991.c-Net lossYear-ago share earnings for the quarter reflects accretion to fair value of a warrant and the accretion of dividends on preferred stock.

title: INTELLIGENCE CHIEF TELLS ABOUT PLAN FOR CHANGING ERA
description: Robert M. Gates, the new Director of Central Intelligence, said today that he intended to shrink America's espionage agencies by billions of dollars and thousands of employees and reorganize them for a world in which the Soviet Union was no longer the primary threat to world order.

title: Mets' Search For Pitchers Is Strictly Top of Line
description: For the Mets, the hunt is for pitching, top-caliber pitching. The landscape, to their chagrin if not surprise, isn't rich with targets.

title: New Jersey Called No. 1 in Northeast in the Cost of Political Races
description: Driven by the need to advertise in such high-priced markets as New York City and Philadelphia, by a proliferation of political action committees and by a lack of campaign contribution limits, New Jersey has become the most expensive state in the Northeast for state political campaigning, according to election officials and experts.

title: Working for the Japanese: Job Stability, but Long Hours
description: Until a few years ago, when Ghwee Kok Thai thought about Japan, it was through the stories of his father, one of the millions of Malaysians who were forced to learn the Japanese language, follow the commands of the Japanese Army and absorb Japanese culture after Japan ousted Britain as the colonial ruler of Malaya.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- Addenda; People
description: * Justin L. Harrington has been named a senior vice president and director for operations and strategy at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York. He had previously been senior vice president and group director at Ogilvy & Mather New York. * Philip Davidson has been named a senior vice president and co-creative director at Ketchum Advertising New York. He previously had been senior vice president and associate creative director at Cadwell Davis Partners, New York.

title: Review/Television; Pearl Harbor, as Both Sides Saw It
description: Let no one charge that the 50th anniversary of Pearl Harbor caught television by surprise.

title: Autodie reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 1,549,498, or 29 cents a share.The company said most of the loss for fiscal 1991 was due to a $ 30.5 million write-down during the fourth quarter in order to implement a plan approved by the Autodie board of directors that fundamentally reduces the size of the company.Of the $ 30.5 million write-down in the fourth quarter, about $ 24.7 million is related to real estate, machinery and equipment.

title: Tax-Exempt Funds Post A Slight Increase in Yields
description: Yields on tax-exempt money market funds tended to rise a little during the last week, but yields on taxable money market funds showed a moderate decline, according to IBC/ Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about "A Day Without Art," an observance for people who have died of AIDS, misidentified the organizer of a special exhibition, "A Space Without Art," at the Museum of Modern Art. It was the museum's projects committee.

title: HAITIANS WIN STAY ON FORCED RETURN
description: In a ruling that maintains a temporary ban on the forced repatriation of Haitians fleeing their country, a Federal District Court in Miami has ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to devise new procedures to screen refugees and assure that no Haitians with a legitimate fear of persecution are sent back.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- Addenda; Della Femina Halts Miami Office Plan
description: With yesterday's shutdown of Pan American World Airways, Della Femina McNamee Inc., New York, has abandoned plans to open a Miami office to serve the airline's advertising account.

title: Hadco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
10-Day Sales Of Vehicles Up by 20.9%
description: Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks rose 20.9 percent in late November, auto makers reported today, but sales for the full month were down 6.7 percent from last year's level.

title: Words of Care Go With Gifts To Neediest
description: "This year more than last year, more than previous years, the need for your fund is apparent to any person who observes our city," Arthur Tenenholtz of Brooklyn wrote to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "Although my employer has not granted a pay raise this year, I am increasing my donation."

title: G.O.P. Senator Opposes Using Rail Funds to Limit Subway Fare
description: With a fight looming in the Legislature over fare increases for mass transit in New York City, a powerful Republican Senator said today that he would adamantly oppose any attempt to transfer money from construction funds used for commuter railroads to the city's subway and bus lines.

title: Wirtz Lacking 'the Vision Thing'
description: A month ago, when the National Hockey League Board of Governors met in New York, the members briefly considered a letter of resignation from William Wirtz, the chairman, who is also the owner of the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: U.N. Envoy to Discuss German Hostages
description: The United Nations envoy who has been negotiating the fate of Western hostages in Lebanon is expected to visit Bonn on Thursday, officials said, in the wake of reports suggesting that the two remaining hostages, both Germans, may soon be freed.

title: Bonilla Brings Joy to Bronx, But Old School Strikes Out
description: When Bobby Bonilla signed a $29 million dollar contract with the Mets this week and became the highest paid athlete in professional team sports, the South Bronx native was quick to say he wanted to go home to his old neighborhood and start giving something back.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the cleanup of a lot in the South Bronx referred incorrectly to the owner's lawyer. He is Aaron Gelbwaks.

title: When Housing Gives Drugs a Roof
description: Sunlight barely penetrates the gloom of 1055 University Avenue in the Bronx. Darkness fills its corridors and stairwells, obscuring the kinetic grafitti, the clumps of discarded clothing, the bulging bags of garbage and the grimy tile. Many of the apartments, with cracked ceilings, creaky floors and gaping rat holes, are hardly any better and sometimes just as dim.

title: Treasury Prices Continue to Rise
description: Prices of Treasury securities continued to rise and interest rates moved lower again yesterday, as investors eager to capture higher yields concentrated their purchases on longer-term notes and bonds.
