title: Son Picks Up Nobel Prize for a Detained Burmese Dissenter
description: The 18-year-old son of the Burmese opposition leader accepted the Nobel Peace Prize for his mother today, declaring her confinement by the military Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, to be "part of a much larger struggle, worldwide, for the emancipation of the human spirit and freedom from psychological subjection."

title: In Gifts for Cooks, Think of the Basics
description: THE unmistakable trend in cooking today is toward unfussy, homestyle fare. This movement back to basics can be seen everywhere from leading French and American restaurants to dinner parties at home.

title: Jersey City Mayor Testifies in His Defense
description: Just as his two-week criminal fraud trial was about to end in Federal District Court here, Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City decided today to take the stand in his own defense.

title: 'Nick and Nora' to Close
description: "Nick and Nora," a musical written and directed by Arthur Laurents with music by Charles Strouse and lyrics by Richard Maltby Jr., is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 45th Street. The Sunday matinee of the play, starring Barry Bostwick, Joanna Gleason and Christine Baranski, will be its ninth regular performance; it had 71 previews.

title: Moguls: Up and Away
description: Moguls is a ski event that combines freestyle aerials, speed and turning maneuvers down a steep course that is usually just under a quarter of a mile in length.

title: WNET to Sell Rights To 'Charlie Rose'
description: WNET, Channel 13, will sell rebroadcast rights to its talk program "Charlie Rose" to the Learning Channel, executives at the station and the cable channel announced yesterday.

title: CML Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 1,649,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: Central Park Holds First Rat D-Day
description: A mild, windless morning, lighted by bright sun. Everyone agreed it was a perfect day for poisoning rats in Central Park.

title: Knicks Clobber Nets, But Not Unexpectedly
description: Two professional basketball teams were scheduled to play at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight. Only one team seemed genuinely interested. The Nets, a team with an embattled coach and inept players, disintegrated early and were manhandled by the Knicks, 114-88.

title: Transmedia Network reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Local Ownership Will Control Islanders
description: Almost a year after he put the Islanders up for sale, John O. Pickett Jr. said last night that he had agreed to sell a minority interest in the team to a group of Long Island investors who would take over active control of the operation. Pickett, who did not disclose the price, said the investors had options to acquire a half interest within five years.

title: Excavation Brings Woe To Neighbor
description: The 19th-century building that houses the New York City Planning Department is sagging, shaking and cracking because of foundation work that is meant to protect it from the construction next door of a new Federal office tower.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Rev. M. WILLIAM HOWARD JR. of Lawrenceville, N.J., has been elected the ninth president of the New York Theological Seminary. He is the first black to head the seminary, which has the city's largest program preparing men and women for the Protestant ministry.

title: Applied Extrusion Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 457,000 on the payment of long-term debt.c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day in some copies yesterday about plans to begin selling the Large Type Weekly of The New York Times next week on some newsstands in Florida misstated the single-copy price. It will be $1.25.

title: U.S. WEIGHS PLANS FOR FOES OF IRAQI
description: The Bush Administration is reviewing military options on how the United States would respond to a coup in Iraq by senior members of the Iraqi armed forces, Administration officials said today.

title: Buchanan, Urging New Nationalism, Joins '92 Race
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, entered the race for the Republican Presidential nomination today with a biting attack on foreign aid and President Bush's "globalist" passions, and with a plea for a new nationalism.

title: The Slow-Growth Monster
description: The wait-and-see economics of President Bush has taken a heavy toll. The drop in November's employment sharply raises the odds that the recession isn't ending. In a time of high debt, the biggest dangers lie ahead. But the President persists. Yesterday, inching closer to the facts, he called the economy's performance "unacceptable," but offered no new proposals for growth. He plans to wait until January.

title: Seton Hall Is Getting Ready for a Lively Rutgers Reception
description: The gymnasium in Piscataway, N.J., where Rutgers University plays its basketball games is called the Rac, and not only because it is the acronym for the Rutgers Athletic Center. title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Aggies Upset the Utes Todd Gentry made two free throws with 7 seconds remaining in overtime last night to seal Utah State's 74-72 victory over Utah (6-1) in Salt Lake City. Utah led, 58-51, with 5 minutes left in regulation but the Aggies closed with an 11-4 run to tie it at 62-62 and force overtime. Malloy Nesmith and Kendall Youngblood scored 13 points each to lead Utah State (2-2). (AP) Indiana 88, Vanderbilt 51: Three of Indiana's usual starters spent the first half on the bench, but Greg Graham and Matt Nover each scored 14 points and the Hoosiers, playing at home in Bloomington, Ind., went on to rout Vanderbilt, 88-51. Calbert Cheaney, Indiana's leading scorer; Eric Anderson, and Damon Bailey did start in the second half and made their presence known immediately by scoring Indiana's first 9 points. (AP) Temple 92, Illinois 56: Mik Kilgore scored 19 of his 27 points in the first half last night as the Owls (3-0) trounced the Illini, 92-56, in Philadelphia. It was Illinois' worst defeat since Feb. 9, 1974, when it lost to Indiana, 107-67. (AP) Oklahoma 106, Texas 91: Not having Dexter Cambridge, who was declared ineligible Monday, left a big hole in the middle of the Texas lineup, and the Sooners' Bryan Sallier took advantage. Sallier scored 24 points and grabbed a career-high 20 rebounds in leading the Sooners (5-0) at home in Norman. (AP) N.B.A. Pacers Edge Spurs Reggie Miller scored 25 points, including a key layup in the final moments, as the Indiana Pacers beat the San Antonio Spurs, 109-102, in Indianapolis. It was the Spurs' fifth consecutive defeat. (AP) Hawks 118, Bucks 104: Dominique Wilkins scored 41 points and Kevin Willis had 24 points and 14 rebounds as Atlanta, playing at home, took control in the second quarter and then raced past Milwaukee. Moses Malone, returning to Atlanta for the first time since signing with the Bucks, led Milwaukee with a season-high 27 points. (AP) Bulls 108, SuperSonics 103: Centers Stacey King and Will Perdue, averaging a combined 13.8 points, scored a total of 35 points to help Chicago win at home. Ricky Pierce led the Sonics with 30 points and hit all five of his free throws to give him 68 without a miss, 10 short of the league record set by Calvin Murphy of Houston in 1980-81. (AP) Rockets 108, Trail Blazers 106: Hakeem Olajuwon scored 15 of his 25 points in a fourth-quarter rally as Houston broke a five-game losing streak, on the road in Portland. (AP) TENNIS Chang Beats Courier Michael Chang upset the French Open champion, Jim Courier, in straight sets yesterday in the $6 million Grand Slam Cup at Munich, Germany. Early in the day, Boris Becker of Germany was forced to withdraw because of a virus and Jimmy Connors lost to Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 0-6, 6-4, 6-4. Becker was replaced by Todd Woodbridge. The event, the richest in the game, was supposed to feature the 16 players with the best results from the four 1991 Grand Slam tournaments, but it now includes only one 1991 Grand Slam champion: the Wimbledon winner, Michael Stich of Germany, who will play Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia today. Chang easily eliminated the second-ranked Courier, 6-4, 6-2. Ivan Lendl sailed past Cristiano Caratti of Italy, 6-4, 6-1. Patrick McEnroe rallied to beat Thierry Champion of France, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4. (AP) SKIING Victory for Tomba Alberto Tomba scored his third World Cup victory of the season yesterday, winning a slalom at Sestriere, Italy. The 24-year-old Italian had the best time in first heat and the third best in the second heat for a winning aggregate time of 2 minutes 49 seconds, 0.91 seconds better than Finn Christian Jagge of Norway. (AP)

description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in Simon & Schuster v. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the opinion for the Court, which was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Byron R. White, John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia and David H. Unlikely Bedfellows Put New Spin on Trenton Tax Debate
description: Like a troupe of dismayed and disillusioned Aladdins, Trenton Republicans and their allies in business, who wished for a rollback of the new taxes imposed by the Democrats last year, are trying desperately to coax the genie back into the magic lamp. Their wish may suddenly be granted, and they don't like it a bit.

title: Books of The Times; A Call for Freedom, From an Unstifled Voice
description: Freedom From Fear And Other Writings By Aung San Suu Kyi Edited with an Introduction by Michael Aris Illustrated. 338 pages. Penguin Books. $12 (paperback). Viking Press. $25 (hard cover).

title: Chicago Rivet & Machine Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alias Research reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a $ 5,047,000 reserve for accounts receivable and a $ 850,000 restructuring charge in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net income

title: Catherine Stores Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Miller-Trial Jury to Return
description: Ending its third day of deliberations, the jury in the trial of Mel Miller was excused for the night yesterday after sending out a note that said, "We are very tired; tempers are rising." Judge Raymond J. Dearie, conducting the fraud trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, sent the jury home and said the deliberations would resume at 10 A.M. today. Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat who is the New York State Assembly Speaker, and a top aide, Jay Adolf, are charged with defrauding their law firm's clients in a series of investments in cooperative apartments.

title: Fronteer Directory Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Somali Fighting Keeps Aid From a Suffering City
description: Artillery shelling in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, worsened today, preventing a last-ditch attempt to unload a Red Cross ship with badly needed supplies for the war-torn city, aid workers said.

title: Prime Medical Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $ 817,000 on the sale of an equity investment.c-Net loss

title: McFarland Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net charge of $ 8,506,000 from writedown of oil and gas properties.c-Net income

title: Shearson Negotiating Sale Of Mortgage Banking Unit
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. is negotiating to sell its mortgage banking unit for $238 million to a group of Middle Eastern and American investors, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Assigned Domingo Mota, second baseman, to Baseball City of the Florida State League.

title: Lavalintech reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included $ 3,153,609 of expenses on the Magnola project, a joint venture with a unit of Noranda Inc. to develop a new magnesium production technology. Lavalintech said the amount reflects its total expenses to date on Magnola, net of government research grants. Lavalintech also said it decided to expense its investment in Magnola because the project is now under review due to excess capacity in the magnesium market and it now appears that a start-up of the project won't take place as soon as orginally expected.c-Net income

title: Council Election Losers Say Winner Doesn't Live There
description: Some of the losers in the election for the new 18th Council District in the Bronx filed a complaint yesterday in State Supreme Court contending that City Councilwoman-elect Lucy Cruz does not live in the district she is to represent. In fact, they say, she doesn't live in New York City at all.

title: In the Nation; Who's Sorry Now?
description: Another election year is just around the corner, so here's a piece of advice that candidates for dogcatcher or President would do well to observe: Be careful what you promise. It could come back to haunt you.

title: Incinerators: Unwanted and Politically Dangerous
description: This is where the voters of Monmouth County decided to save the earth.

title: Review/Theater; A Politically Correct 'Two Gentlemen'
description: Largely because of its ending, "Two Gentlemen of Verona" has always been one of Shakespeare's more problematic comedies. How can one make psychological sense of the story of two friends, Proteus and Valentine, whose relationship is betrayed when Proteus pursues and sexually assaults his best friend's true love, Sylvia, and is then instantly forgiven?

title: Books of The Times; Bats on the Backcast, Life on the Line
description: Batfishing in the Rainforest Strange Tales of Travel and Fishing By Randy Wayne White 250 pages. Lyons & Burford. $19.95.

title: National Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Included a first quarter restructuring charge of $ 149.3 million taken in connection with the company's plans to consolidate its worldwide manufacturing capacity.c-Included a restructuring charge of $ 141.2 million.

title: Camel's Success and Controversy
description: A ubiquitous advertising campaign that presents an anthropomorphic camel as a "smooth character" has once again come in for rough treatment. But the latest attacks are being shrugged off by a company thrilled over the campaign's continuing success in replenishing the ranks of customers for a product that loses hundreds of thousands of consumers a year.

title: Islanders Are Staying Home, but Will Get a New Look
description: It isn't the sale to end all sales, but it has, at least for the foreseeable future, ended speculation that Long Island was on the verge of losing its only professional sports team, the New York Islanders.

title: U.S. ENDORSES PACT ON EUROPEAN UNITY
description: The United States today welcomed the pact by European Community heads of state to seek greater political and economic union, but President Bush warned against limits on American exports.

title: Missouri Town Is Shaken by Shooting Spree
description: Slowly this shaken town in the hills of central Missouri began to come out from behind its barred doors and shuttered windows and live free again today as James R. Johnson was led into the red-brick county courthouse.

title: Boston Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of securities of $ 6,622,000 in latest quarter and a loss of $ 12,806,000 in the yearc-Included a loss on the sale of securities of $ 259,000 in the quarter and a gain of $ 2,596,000 in the year, and the year also included a gain of $ 841,000 on the sale of mortgage servicing.

title: Macy's Lenders Agree To New Deal on Credit
description: In a move that substantially eases its short-term cash pressure, R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that it had renegotiated an important credit agreement with its lenders.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A furor has erupted in South Africa over a remark attributed to the country's contender for the 1991 Miss World crown. Miss Nigeria, ABENIKE OSHINOWO, said Miss South Africa, DIANA TILDEN-DAVIS, told her that few blacks entered her country's pageant because most black women "fall pregnant by the age of 15."

title: Twins Extend Kelly
description: For the second time in three months, the Minnesota Twins have extended the contract of Manager TOM KELLY, this time through the 1994 season.

title: Huffman Koos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Estimate on Maxwells' Debts Rise
description: The Robert Maxwell family's private companies, which are in bankruptcy, may be laboring under far more debt than previously estimated, it was disclosed today, raising the likelihood that the companies' banks, suppliers, employees and other creditors face a loss of at least $1.6 billion.

title: Conrail Plans Big Write-Off
description: Conrail said it would take an after-tax charge of up to $450 million in the current quarter to cover write-offs of rail lines that were underutilized and other assets, a pending labor agreement that would cut the size of train crews and other matters. Conrail, or the Consolidated Rail Corporation, operates in 14 states, Washington, D.C., and Quebec.

title: Soviet Writer Wins Dance Book Award
description: A Soviet writer has, for the first time, won the De la Torre Bueno Prize awarded annually in New York for the most distinguished book of dance scholarship. Elizabeth Souritz, the head of the dance section of the Moscow Institute for the History of Arts, received the prize for her book, "Soviet Choreographers in the 1920's," published by Duke University Press.

title: Nordson Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
TRW Plans Asset Sales And Cost Cut
description: TRW Inc., the Cleveland-based automotive, space, defense and information conglomerate, said yesterday that it would sell businesses worth $400 million to $500 million; cut capital spending by more than $100 million next year, or more than 16 percent, and lay off 2,500. The company's stock jumped nearly 8 percent on the news.

title: Cott Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,669,000 from the sale of real estate for both the quarter and 9 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ardent Miniaturists Make Mini-Wonders With Their Hands
description: IN Renee T. Wilson's unfinished Victorian mansion, St. George struggles with the dragon in etched glass. The garden room will have a working fountain. Plans for the billiard room include horn furniture.

title: Bringing In a Wanted Man: Scores of Officers, Nothing in Writing
description: Early yesterday morning, a plainclothes New York City police officer boarded a plane to Washington on a highly confidential mission: to escort back to Manhattan a writer traveling under an international sentence of death.

title: Agent Says Volek Is Upset And Wants to Be Traded
description: The agent for David Volek said yesterday the Islanders forward was seeking to be traded because no progress had been made in negotiations for a new contract with General Manager Bill Torrey.

title: On Calling People by Their Rightful Names; Hatch's Condescension
description: To the Editor:

title: Houses the Cows Would Love to Eat
description: IT takes stamina. It takes commitment. It takes a lot of antihistamines.

title: Legislature Drops Wage Tax by Vote Weicker Can Veto
description: The drive to undo Connecticut's new wage tax suffered a major setback tonight when the Senate passed a repeal bill by a majority too weak to survive a certain veto by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: Old Merchant's House To Reopen in Manhattan
description: To walk into the Old Merchant's House in Manhattan, which has nearly all its original furniture, bone china, stoneware, and coverlets, is to enter the 19th century. The house, at 29 East Fourth Street (near the Bowery), will reopen to the public Sunday after nine months of restoration.

title: Review/Dance; The Ailey Troupe Presents a World Premiere
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater offered a relatively subdued gala benefit on Tuesday night at the City Center. Moreover, "Rift," the program's world premiere by Judith Jamison, the troupe's artistic director, did not exactly have a festive theme.

title: It Sounds Radical, But It Makes Sense
description: With expansion to Tampa and Ottawa almost a certainty for next season, the National Hockey League faces a major political problem with divisional realignment. Despite hours of log-rolling last week at the Board of Governors meeting, the executives couldn't divide the 24 teams into four groups of six in a way that would please the necessary two-thirds majority. They will try again in January.

title: Washington at Work; Dole, Bush's Point Man in the Senate, Is Considering Life Behind the Lines
description: Bob Dole did more with less in the last session of Congress, extricating his party from White House-made difficulties on civil rights and unemployment benefits. But the Republican leader of the Senate sounds tired of keeping the increasingly fractious, dwindling Republican minority together.

title: Midwesco Filter Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Quayle Returns Critics' Fire on Conflict of Interest
description: Vice President Dan Quayle lashed out today at several committee chairmen in Congress for raising accusations of conflict of interest against him and his staff, and said his Council on Competitiveness would carry on with efforts to reduce regulation of American business.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the San Damiano friary in the Bronx and The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misstated the relationship between the friary and the fund. The friary no longer receives money from the Neediest Cases appeal. Its yearly grant from Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, one of seven charities affiliated with the Neediest Cases, was canceled, the charity said, so the money could be used to meet the rising need for food and rent assistance.

title: Wiener Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-After a loss of $ 468,000 from discontinued operations in the quarter and 9 months.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 673,000 in the quarter and $ 803,000 in the 9 months.

title: Virco Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Owens-Illinois Share Demand
description: Last month, Owens-Illinois Inc. figured it could go public at $13 to $16 a share, raising as much as $960 million. But the company's investment bankers said there was not enough demand at those levels.

title: First Group of Exiles Returns to South Africa Under U.N. Amnesty
description: The first group of exiles to return to South Africa under an amnesty negotiated by the United Nations with the South African Government arrived in Johannesburg this morning and were greeted by a jubilant crowd.

title: Panel Urges Big Wetlands Restoration Project
description: A panel of scientists recommended yesterday that the United States undertake an ambitious long-term program of ecological restoration intended to move the nation beyond the Bush Administration's policy of "no net loss" of wetlands and to make damaged rivers, lakes and streams healthy again.

title: Foundations Bolster Fund For Neediest
description: Although most donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are individuals who contribute $100 or less, many foundations provide larger sums in joining the effort to help the city's sick, poor and disabled.

title: Willoughby Brazeau, An Exporter, Dies at 87
description: Willoughby F. Brazeau, a retired business executive who promoted foreign-trade groups and was decorated by five nations for his service in World War II, died on Friday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 87 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Robert Maxwell's Shell Game
description: Robert Maxwell was hailed as a philanthropic savior when he bought New York's strike-torn, dispirited Daily News in March, just as he was when he revived London's languishing Daily Mirror in 1984. Now, sadly, both The News and The Mirror seem little more than pawns in a vast and duplicitous game that Mr. Maxwell was playing with other people's money.

title: Review/Dance; A Mix of Solos, Rituals and Satire at Dia
description: The Performance Mix fall series came to an enjoyably rowdy end on Monday night at the Dia Center for the Arts on Mercer Street in SoHo. The program opened on a relatively serene note with two dance solos by Dennis O'Connor. In "Low Dance," set to music by Christine Bacyewska, Mr. O'Connor crashed, rippled and crawled about the stage in a surprisingly unforced and unabrasive fashion, pausing for fleeting moments of stillness. The solo, a study for a new group work, looked far less finished than "Slake," a recent dance performed nude and in silence, which remains an inspired portrait of an exceptionally crisp and luminous dancer.

title: Mariners Obtain Mitchell From Giants for 3 Pitchers
description: Kevin Mitchell, his big bat and his big salary were shipped north from San Francisco to Seattle today. The Mariners had sought a big bat, but their willingness to accept a big salary surprised executives of other clubs.

title: Isuzu Signs Up For Super Bowl Spot
description: CBS has landed the first automotive advertiser for its telecast of Super Bowl XXVI on Jan. 26, American Isuzu Motors Inc.

title: Metro Mobile Cts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After about $ 1.9 million of expenses relating to the merger agreement signed with the Bell Atlantic Corp. The losses are also after a one-time charge of $ 16.9 million related to the writeoff of deferred financing costs in connection with Metro Mobile's cellular credit agreement.

title: Century Telephone Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included one-time gain of $ 2,591,000, or 8 cents a share, for sale of investment.Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Mets Give Up McReynolds and Get Saberhagen
description: Five hours after General Manager Al Harazin conceded temporary defeat by saying "I can't seem to romance" the ace pitcher he had sought all week, the Mets executed a stunning five-player trade tonight. They acquired Bret Saberhagen, a two-time Cy Young Award winner, and sent Kevin McReynolds, Gregg Jefferies and Keith Miller to the Kansas City Royals.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
We Koreans Need An Al Sharpton
description: A gang of masked men rampaged through a Korean-American grocery in Brooklyn Tuesday, injuring two store employees. The police are investigating the assault as a bias-related incident. But, like most attacks on Korean-Americans, it will quickly be forgotten by most New Yorkers and the media.

title: Utley Is Transferred
description: MIKE UTLEY, the Detroit Lions' offensive lineman who is paralyzed from the chest down after being injured during a game on Nov. 17, has been transferred to a rehabilitation center near Denver.

title: Business, Like the Voters, Is Worrying About the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Charter Medical Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge for reserves related to the company's previously reported financial restructuring of $ 45 million in the latest year and $ 105 million in the year-earlier period.c-Included a loss of $ 7,567,000 from a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21 DISAGREE, DA; FIGHT, NYET

title: Buck Clayton, Jazz Trumpeter In the Basie Orchestra, Dies at 80
description: Buck Clayton, a jazz trumpeter who was a star of Count Basie's orchestra in the late 1930's and early 40's, died on Sunday at a friend's home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Value Line Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
On Calling People by Their Rightful Names
description: To the Editor:

title: Hostetler Out for Rest of Season
description: Jeff Hostetler's season is over. The Giants placed their starting quarterback on injured reserve today and signed Mike Perez, who had been with them twice previously, as a free-agent backup for the last two games.

title: Treasuries Move in Narrow Range
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved in a narrow range and interest rates were little changed yesterday, as credit market participants positioned themselves in advance of substantive reports on inflation and the economy.

title: Garden History, Sublime and Ridiculous
description: MAC GRISWOLD was brought up to believe in the value of the brisk walk, and every day after school, that was her habit. (She also got very cold at night sleeping with the windows open, but that vigorous experience didn't seep into her soul the way the walks did.)

title: Daily News and Its Unions Start Committee on How to Cut Costs
description: Representatives of The Daily News management and unions met yesterday to begin work on a reorganization that they hoped would cut the bankrupt newspaper's costs and let it keep operating. The two-hour meeting left both sides expressing confidence that the paper could be saved.

title: Israel Braces for Influx From Slavic Regions
description: Already struggling, and in many instances failing, to cope with the tide of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union, Israeli officials warned today that the latest Soviet turmoil could set off a new wave of immigration that would catch this country unprepared.

title: Computer Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Asset Sales By Marriott
description: The Marriott Corporation, which built a reputation on quality hotels and airline catering, plans to reduce its debt by as much as $1 billion over three years, from $3.5 billion.

title: Students' Trucks Are Carlike
description: IN the year 2,000, pickup trucks may look sleek, streamlined and sporty, and still be able to carry 4-by-8-foot sheets of plywood. That is, if students at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., have their way.

title: Where Do Giants Turn for a Lift When All Appears to Be Lost?
description: When the National Football League schedule came out in April, it looked like a dream game: The Giants against the Washington Redskins on the next-to-last Sunday of the season.

title: Talks on Europe 'Decisive,' German Chancellor Asserts
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that this week's European Community summit meeting was a "decisive breakthrough" on the way to continental unity, but critics at home said they wished it had been more successful.

title: U.S. Should Take Lead on East Timor; Almost 100 Killed
description: To the Editor:

title: A Range Beloved of Pros Can Now Be Everyone's
description: SINCE 1864 Garland Commercial Industries has successfully flip-flopped from producing ranges for homes through the 1970's, then for restaurants, and now for both.

title: Du Pont Says U.S. Cleared Export Of Item Used in Iraqi Bomb Effort
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11 --

title: U.S. Is Assailed on Bank Regulation
description: The Government's top auditor told Congress today that the Bush Administration's latest cure for what it calls a credit crunch would instead make the problem worse, hiding the symptoms of sick banks and further draining the fund that protects bank deposits.

title: Essay; Gorby Invites the Deluge
description: Revealing the true colors of a tyrant, Mikhail Gorbachev now seeks to thwart the democratic will of the independent republics of his former empire by bidding for the support of the veteran Red Army generals.

title: THE EUROPEAN SUMMIT: Europe at Crossroads; Leaders Return From Meetings Confident That Region Will Move Onward to Union
description: After the deadlocks, squabbles and veto threats that frequently marred their negotiations, European Community leaders returned home today confident that their two-day summit meeting here would be remembered as a turning-point in the region's decades-old integration process.

title: At North General, Moving a Whole Hospital, One Patient at a Time
description: This morning, at 5 o'clock, the chief doctors and administrators of North General Hospital will synchronize their watches. At precisely 7 A.M. their emergency room will close and, simultaneously, re-open up the street.

title: Kleinman To Pursue Suit Against Vincent
description: A suddenly defiant Leonard Kleinman, the Yankees' chief operating officer, said today that he had no intention of dropping a lawsuit against Commissioner Fay Vincent.

title: Quotation Of The Day
description: "Free speech is life itself." -- SALMAN RUSHDIE. [ A1:4. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Robin Hood Foundation presented its second annual heroes' awards yesterday to the directors of three community organizations that fight poverty in New York City.

title: Health-Mor reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 206,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Hyping the Soviet Nuclear Peril
description: There are 27,000 nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union -- a fact that is supposed to capture the magnitude of the alleged security crisis we are facing and to stress the urgency for U.S. action. It should do neither. While there are reasons for concern and for active U.S. diplomacy, the hyping of a new Soviet nuclear threat has gotten out of hand.

title: Excerpts From Rushdie's Address: 1,000 Days 'Trapped Inside a Metaphor'
description: Following are excerpts from a speech at Columbia University last night by Salman Rushdie. The speech was adapted from a forthcoming essay titled "One Thousand Days in a Balloon":

title: Admar Group reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
No Headline
description: IT is not a museum, but each of its objects, whether a Napoleonic chair or a clothes brush, is a work of art.

title: Central Sprinkler reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Concern About Arms Control
description: The Administration is confident there is no threat to American security from the Soviet upheaval, but fears that the system of nuclear arms control may be breaking down. Page A13.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY SALMAN RUSHDIE EMERGES FROM HIDING

title: Bridge
description: The luckiest player of 1991 may well be Richard Schwartz of Floral Park, L.I. The evidence is the diagramed deal from the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship in Indianapolis last month, on which his own skill and a slight defensive misjudgment were needed to supplement the beneficence of the fates.

title: HUNTS POINT JOURNAL Ambitious Bronx Youths Find Profit in Vacant Lot
description: Dusk settled over a windswept South Bronx street as several teen-agers chopped an agricultural product that they will later stash into bags. The next day these same youths would deliver the goods to chic addresses on the East Side and in Greenwich Village, where their customers would rip open the bags, burn their contents and savor the sweet-smelling smoke.

title: Devtek Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Leap to Unity in Europe
description: A generation from now when schoolchildren study Europe's resurgence after World War II, they may well focus on this week's summit meeting in the Dutch city of Maastricht as a decisive event. Members of the European Community approved treaties that will forge common economic, foreign and defense policies. The idea is to propel Europe into the 21st century as a cohesive power able to meet economic and political challenges from North America and Asia.

title: When Coslet Says Nothing, Jets Read Between the Silence
description: Whatever it was that came over Coach Bruce Coslet when he sat down this morning to try to compose some inspirational words for his Jets players, it wasn't writer's block.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Milt Jackson Blue Note

title: New Sunrise for Palace
description: THE SUN KING has become a logo. Last month, Jean-Baptiste Blom and Juliette Weisbuch, founders of Polymago, a graphic design agency in Paris, created a stylized blue Apollo -- the emblem of Louis XIV -- for the official logo of the national museum at Versailles.

title: How Water Projects Fall Behind
description: To alleviate extremely low water pressure in the southern part of Staten Island, the city's Environmental Protection Department planned to replace 50,000 feet of 20-inch water mains last year. It hasn't happened yet: The city's General Services Department was late in providing street surveys of the area.

title: Home Video
description: The emphasis on hit movies in video stores tends to obscure thousands of other titles available on tape. Nowhere is the deluge of material better demonstrated than in catalogues like the one from Movies Unlimited of Philadelphia, a chain of stores in New Jersey and Pennsylvania that also sells videos by mail order. In 1991, the catalogue, which is one of the most comprehensive listings in the country, carried some 22,000 titles of all kinds. The 2-pound 1992 edition has an estimated 25,000 entries.

title: Brooklyn College Firsts: Marshall and Rhodes
description: They are classmates now in Brooklyn, and they will be classmates next fall at Oxford University in England: the first Rhodes Scholar and the first Marshall Scholar in the 61-year history of Brooklyn College.

title: Zapata Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $ 46.5 million in the quarter and $ 70.8 million in the year. The losses from discontinued operations included losses from disposal of discontinued operations of $ 14.3 million in the quarter and $ 38.6 million in the year, and loss on disposal of drilling assets of $ 32.2 million in the quarter and year.

title: On PBS, the Little Engines That Could
description: FOR a lot of young children, this holiday season is turning into a rather joyless lesson about the blunders of big business. They are learning how grown-ups, despite the wisdom of their years, can miscalculate and underestimate, leaving store shelves bare of toys at the top of a great many wish lists.

title: A Growing Choice: Housing or Food
description: When Harold Coleman, a 23-year-old chef's assistant, sketches his family's budget, two figures command attention. He brings home $596 a month. He pays about $480 for rent and utilities for an apartment in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Mental Health Costs Slighted by H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Experts on Rape Back Smith's Acquittal
description: Some experts on rape and the law said yesterday that the jury in West Palm Beach, Fla., had little choice but to acquit William K. Smith of accusations lodged by a Florida woman, given the evidence it was presented.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 8 about several inquiries into persistent but unproven allegations that the Reagan campaign team secretly negotiated with Iran in 1980 to delay the release of American hostages misstated the location of a conference attended by William J. Casey in London that July. Recent letters from readers point out that the conference was at the Imperial War Museum in London, not at a British air base.

title: W.L.A.F. Is Seeking N.F.L. Talent
description: The National Football League and the World League of American Football are working out a plan to have each N.F.L. team make available four players to W.L.A.F. teams, according to officials from both leagues. The plan is expected to be approved at an N.F.L. owners' meeting in Dallas next Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Maybe Walls Go Better, Too
description: FOR those who find the past more comforting than the present, the Coca-Cola Company has created wallpaper that is a collage of nostalgia: Coca Cola signs and advertising campaigns from the 40's and 50's.

title: Big Board To Consider Foreign Link
description: Reviving an idea that had appeared dead, the New York Stock Exchange is examining proposals that would allow the stocks of foreign companies to trade on the Big Board, even if the companies do not comply with American accounting standards, the chairman of the exchange said yesterday.

title: Sybil Kooper, 66, Retired Justice Of New York Appellate Division
description: Sybil Hart Kooper, a retired justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in New York, died yesterday at her home in Brooklyn Heights. She was 66 years old.

title: Jack F. Kincannon, Retired Executive, 72
description: Jack F. Kincannon, a retired top executive of Sears, Roebuck & Company, died Dec. 3 at Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. He was 72 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Robbins & Myers reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 408,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Walking the Tightrope That Is 'Marvin's Room'
description: There is an emotional land mine subtly buried in the second act of "Marvin's Room," the new drama by Scott McPherson at Playwrights Horizons. It is triggered by Bessie, the play's heroine, who is provoking laughter from the audience by describing the attention-grabbing antics of a boy named Clarence. Swimming at a picnic, Clarence is clowning around, splashing in the water and making faces to amuse his family on the shore. "Laughing and choking looked the same on Clarence," Bessie says. "He drowned right in front of us." The play's audience, primed to laugh, has suddenly fallen through the trapdoor of tragedy.

title: Reading for the Best Line on Slopes
description: By almost any measure, skiing cannot be called a user-friendly sport. Going up and down a mountain is simple compared with the logistics of getting there, tending equipment, taking lessons, eating, sleeping and snatching a bit of nightlife.

title: INSIDE
description: G.M. Signals Cutbacks; TRW and Xerox Trim Jobs

title: China That Brings Back the Rumble and the Roar
description: A TRAIN fancier all her life, Kathleen Kindig thought she had the perfect job: Owning the B.&O. Railroad Museum gift shop in Baltimore.

title: Review/Cabaret; In Satiric Revue, the Comic Missiles Proliferate
description: The Ensemble Studio Theater has made many noteworthy theatrical contributions during its 20-year history, from giving Macaulay Culkin his first professional role to the discovery of short plays by Christopher Durang, Horton Foote, Romulus Linney and other writers. But until the current In Pursuit of America festival, one area that eluded the company was cabaret comedy. Enter a new image with "Stars in Bars," an outspoken and impertinent satiric revue.

title: Red Cross Worker Wounded As Somali Fighting Goes On
description: A relief worker with the International Committee of the Red Cross was seriously wounded today when he was shot outside a hospital in the war-ravaged Somali capital, Mogadishu, the Red Cross said.

title: Market Place; Device to Save Infants Lifts Medical Hope, and Investors
description: A small California medical-equipment company is stirring hopes both in the medical community and on Wall Street. It is developing a device that could reduce the risk that babies will be born with brain damage because of oxygen deprivation during delivery.

title: Tecnol Medical Products Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Margaret Eyring Moreland, Psychologist, 76
description: Margaret Eyring Moreland, a psychologist who practiced in New York for many years, died on Friday at the New England Medical Center in Boston. She was 76 years old and lived in Yarmouth Port, Mass.

title: Measured Steps Toward One Europe: What Was Decided
description: Economic and Monetary Union

title: Reporter Averts Ceding Interview Tapes
description: A Puerto Rican journalist has reached an agreement with Government prosecutors that allows her to stay out of prison and avoid surrendering the original videotapes of her interviews with two fugitives who are suspects in a robbery in Connecticut.

title: Algerian Opposition Undecided on Elections
description: Two weeks before Algeria's first free parliamentary elections are scheduled to take place, it is still unclear whether the largest opposition group, controlled by Islamic fundamentalists, will take part.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: "CUTTING IN" is a term professional installers use for cutting the opening in a countertop for a new kitchen or bathroom sink. For amateurs, cutting in a sink can be a daunting project; even a small error can ruin an expensive countertop. If you plan carefully, however, the job can be relatively easy.

title: Seoul to Permit Nuclear Inspections
description: The United States and South Korea said today that they would allow North Korea to inspect any civilian or military sites in the country in return for reciprocal rights in the North and an agreement that neither Seoul nor Pyongyang would produce weapons-grade plutonium.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Credit Markets page of Business Day yesterday, headed "Treasury Yield Curve," mislabeled the two yield curves for Treasury securities. The black line represented the current yields, which are lower than the yields a month ago, shown on the white line.

title: Thankful for a Loss
description: BRAD CULPEPPER, a defensive tackle, is thankful for Florida's only loss, 38-21, at Syracuse. "We learned that if we're not fired up and if we don't play like an inspired team we're very average," he said. Since then, Florida (10-1), No. 2 in The New York Times's computer ranking, has won eight in a row, its first Southeastern Conference title and a Sugar Bowl match against Notre Dame. Culpepper, a history major who wants to be a lawyer, was honored yesterday as the Toyota Leader of the Year for his 3.2 average in graduate school.

title: In Major Gain, Alzheimer's Is Cloned in Mice
description: For the first time, researchers have produced genetically modified mice that develop the brain changes seen in Alzheimer's disease.

title: Smith Acquitted of Rape Charge After Brief Deliberation by Jury
description: After deliberating for 77 minutes, a jury acquitted William K. Smith today of charges that he raped a woman at the Kennedy family's Palm Beach estate one moonlit night last Easter weekend.

title: Mets Wait For Pieces To Fall In Place
description: The magnitude of the trade was difficult to digest. For the players, its ramifications weren't easy to accept, either. And the future that the trade laid out in front of the Mets wasn't crystal clear.

title: Romanians Turn From Politics to Economics
description: Anti-Government graffiti scrawled on building walls have become as much a part of Bucharest residents' lives as skyrocketing prices or daylong lines of cars waiting to buy gasoline.

title: China's Prime Minister Arrives in India
description: In a visit that portends major realignments in Asia, China's Prime Minister, Li Peng, arrived here today. It was the first trip by a Chinese head of Government in more than three decades.

title: From Fistfights to Fancy Fighting
description: It was as a grade schooler in Kitchener, Ontario, that Lennox Lewis was expelled from classes for putting his fist through the principal's window.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Samuel K. Skinner, the newly designated White House chief of staff, misidentified the friend whom he has asked to review John H. Sununu's staff operation. The friend is Eugene R. Croisant, executive vice president for human resources and administration at RJR Nabisco.

title: Senator Nunn's Pork Patrol
description: It's not easy for a member of Congress to say no to a colleague seeking funds for a pet hometown project, however dubious. All the more reason to salute last month's valiant if unsuccessful effort by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, to combat pork-barreling by lawmakers in this year's defense budget.

title: Tyson Delay Denied
description: A judge in Indianapolis yesterday turned down a defense request to delay the rape trial of boxer MIKE TYSON.

title: Colombian Resort Basks in the End of Drug Terror
description: When drug traffickers unleashed their terror campaign on this Caribbean tourist port in 1989, they wounded both the city's image and its economy.

title: At Guantanamo Camp, Haitians Fret at Delay
description: As he waited in yet another long line in a dazzling sun, Charmant Wilfred, a lanky 22-year-old, asked a question shared by most of the thousands of Haitian refugees being held here.

title: It's Magic's Moment Again at the Garden
description: The telephone calls from his friends on the East Coast swamped Magic Johnson in Los Angeles. They wanted to know about the rumors. Magic was supposedly feeling ill. Magic was having a negative reaction to AZT. Magic could not travel to Washington to meet with President Bush or to New York for an AIDS function with Donald Trump because he has H.I.V. What was going on with Magic?

title: A.M.A. Acts to Curb Profits From Referrals
description: The American Medical Association has adopted a new policy saying that doctors, in general, should not send patients to clinics, laboratories or other health-care businesses in which the doctors have invested.

title: Xerox Plans to Trim 2,500 From White-Collar Staff
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,500 white-collar jobs, or more than 20 percent of the total, by the middle of next year and take a $175 million pretax charge against earnings in the current quarter to cover the cost.

title: Insurgent Teamster Seems Headed Toward Toppling the Old Guard
description: Rank and file members of the long-corrupt teamsters union appeared headed today toward throwing out their top leadership and electing a dissident, who heads a local of United Parcel Service drivers in Queens, to a five-year term as president.

title: Through Loophole In Tax Law, Art Gifts Pour Into Museums
description: The San Diego Historical Society already knows what it's getting for Christmas: a set of vintage Lionel trains. A museum in Rhode Island has asked for an exotic 17th-century Turkish towel. And the Whitney Museum of American Art has its heart set on a self-portrait by Chuck Close. At the Metropolitan Museum, it's been Christmas all year. Over the last 11 months, the Met has been given $28.3 million worth of art by donors, almost six times more than it received in 1990, including important works by Degas and Pissaro, and an outstanding collection of pre-Columbian gold.

title: Jury Indicts A Detective In Gotti Leaks
description: William Peist seemed so dedicated to tracking Mafia secrets that he went to work on crutches, his fellow detectives recall. But Federal authorities said yesterday that his dedication was to another cause, spying for the mobsters he was supposed to be unmasking.

title: GERMANY RAISING HOPES OF CROATIA
description: As expectations grow here that Germany will soon recognize Croatia, leaders of the republic say they assume the step will be followed by arms shipments or even Western military intervention to help in their uphill battle against the Yugoslav National Army.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
American Film Gets A New Chief Executive
description: American Film Technologies, a production company involved in colorization and computerized animation, yesterday named Joseph M. Taritero president and chief executive, effective Dec. 15.

title: Crash of Private Plane in Georgia Kills 9
description: A corporate jet carrying five top executives of a supermarket chain crashed into a rugged mountainside near this northwest Georgia city today, killing all nine people aboard.

title: Ames Loses $196.3 Million
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. on Tuesday reported a loss of $196.3 million in the third quarter, largely because of a $147.2 million charge for the closing of 77 stores, the company said.

title: Liberal City Elects a Moderate Mayor
description: A pragmatic former police chief who promised to get tough with potholes and panhandlers has won the mayor's race here, defeating the incumbent and the city's liberal establishment.

title: On Calling People by Their Rightful Names; Says What He Thinks
description: To the Editor:

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: CHILDREN, and adults for that matter, tend to receive mixed messages about when and how they should touch each other. While certain types of touch are clearly off limits, the publicity surrounding the sexual abuse and exploitation of children over the last few years has made parents and teachers -- especially male teachers -- question the appropriateness of many expressions of physical affection.

title: 'Son of Sam' Laws, Rightly Reversed
description: Alarmed that the accused serial killer David Berkowitz might reap millions for writing about the "Son of Sam" murders, New York State decided in 1977 to seize literary and movie proceeds from accused or convicted criminals. The Legislature, mindful of the First Amendment problems of penalizing expression, made such seizures part of the state's victim compensation system. Assets would be held for no more than five years; those that were not claimed by crime victims would be given back.

title: Tax Issue Stymies Navratilova Case
description: If death and taxes are life's only certainties, MARTINA NAVRATILOVA and JUDY NELSON, her former companion, may be excused for hoping for the former. It seems tax concerns have thrown the three-month-long negotiations between them back to square one (or is it 1099?). Having failed to settle their palimony suit, the two will probably find themselves back in a Fort Worth courtroom early next year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Editor Quits At Harper's Bazaar
description: Ending perhaps the longest-running rumor in the fashion industry, Anthony T. Mazzola, the editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, announced yesterday that he was stepping down.

title: Democrat Sees a Big '92 Budget Gap in Trenton
description: A major Senate Democrat says New Jersey will not have to wait until the next fiscal year for its economic picture to grow truly grim. By his calculations, the state could find itself $700 million in the red before this budget cycle ends.

title: Pennzoil Move On Exploration
description: The Pennzoil Company said it would shift the focus of its oil and gas exploration to outside the United States. After a board meeting on Tuesday, the company said it would spend up to $100 million a year for three years on foreign exploration, along with its 1992 domestic exploration budget of about $100 million. James L. Pate, the president and chief executive, said the increasing number of foreign areas that have become available represented "a major business opportunity."

title: G.M. Hints Deep Cuts Are Ahead
description: Leading the latest round of corporate shrinkage, the General Motors Corporation signaled investors and employees today that deep cutbacks were in the works.

title: In Arizona, a Bright Christmas
description: IT BEGAN on Halloween, when the trick-or-treaters arrived at Frank Calph's house. Instead of gap-toothed jack o'lanterns and leering skeletons hanging about, they saw snowmen and snowwomen playing fiddles and trumpets, elves and angels scurrying about, a river cascading down a mountain and 20,000 twinkling lights.

title: General Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Included net after-tax gain of $ 1.9 million, or 1 cent a share, from the sale of Pycasa Spanish frozen food unit and restructuring charges related for the Betty Crocker packaged mixes production and European food operations, and the call of 93/8 percent sinking fund debentures due March 1, 2009 for both the quarter and 6 months.c-Included net after-tax gain of $ 9.2 milion, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of Lancia Bravo Pasta operation and a restructuring charge for Yoplaityogurt operations for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months also included a gain of $ 5,700,000 which reflects adjustment of previously established discontinued operations reserves.

title: Republicans in Albany Propose Cuts in Medicaid
description: The Republican-controlled State Senate released a plan today that it said would slash $1.6 billion in spending on Medicaid and welfare over the next 15 months, largely by cutting services and changing eligibility levels for program recipients.

title: Santiago Atitlan Journal; Routed by Village's Rage, a Feared Army Retreats
description: In a country where the army's brutal authority is legendary, the military base just outside this dusty village beside Lake Atitlan is going to seed, its installations unused for the last year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Tobacco Co., Stamford, Conn., named Peter Strauss executive director of trade marketing. * Eddie Bauer, Redmond, Wash., a retailer of outdoor and casual apparel and a unit of Spiegel Inc., named Richard T. Fersch to the newly created position of executive vice president of merchandising and marketing.

title: Rookie Award for Daly
description: JOHN DALY, who won the P.G.A. Championship in August of his first year on tour, and MICHELLE ESTILL received rookie-of-the-year awards from Golf Digest/Rolex. Also honored by Golf Digest were ANDREW MAGEE and MEG MALLON, as the most improved professionals of 1991. FRED COUPLES, PAT BRADLEY and MIKE HILL were named players of the year on the PGA Tour, L.P.G.A. Tour and P.G.A. Senior Tour, respectively, by Golf World magazine. (AP)

title: State Senator Offers Plan To Maintain Transit Fare
description: A powerful Republican State Senator yesterday proposed a plan to save the $1.15 subway and bus fare. The proposal would split the Transit Authority's deficit among New York City, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and unspecified state funds.

title: Sumitomo Bank
description: The Sumitomo Bank of Japan has agreed to extend its $500 million investment in Goldman, Sachs & Company into the next century, Goldman said. Sumitomo made the original investment in 1986, with a little-noticed escape clause that allowed either party the option to initiate a withdrawal of the investment in 1996. Goldman said the companies had agreed to extend the earliest date for a possible withdrawal to "beyond 2001," but did not give further information. The Sumitomo investment entitles the bank to 12.5 percent of Goldman's profits.

title: North Hempstead Aide Charged With Perjury in a Family Feud
description: A caustic family feud over an Old Westbury, L.I., estate spilled into criminal court today when a North Hempstead official was indicted on charges of perjury and other criminal acts related to his purportedly paying a witness to sign false affidavits.

title: Analogic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Jack Tannen, 84, Whose Shop Of Old Books Was a Rarity, Too
description: Jack Tannen, a retired antiquarian bookseller whose lower Manhattan emporium was a mecca for book lovers, died early Tuesday in Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: Autopsy Indicates Maxwell Did Not Drown
description: The long-awaited autopsy report on Robert Maxwell, scheduled to be released this week, says the British publishing tycoon apparently did not die of drowning but probably suffered a heart attack, even though the autopsy found no evidence of such an attack, according to the forensic doctor who prepared the report.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RONALD O. PERELMAN, the financier and chairman of Revlon, has donated $10 million to the New York University Medical Center, and the university's medical school has named its dermatology department for him. Mr. Perelman, who bought Revlon in 1985 for $1.8 billion, has been a trustee of the medical center, at First Avenue and 32d Street, since 1982. He donated $1 million to the center's cardiac catheterization unit in 1983.

title: Europe's Pact on Money Seen as Business Boon
description: The European Community's bold plan to create a common central bank and currency promises large long-term gains, but sharp short-term pains for Europe's economy.

title: Now It's Pfizer on a Roll In a High-Risk Business
description: After seven dry years without important new drugs, Pfizer has broken through with a cornucopia of winners. New products are already generating $1.1 billion this year for the big New York-based health-care company, pushing its pharmaceutical sales to $3.8 billion from $3.2 billion in 1990 and making Pfizer's drug unit one of the largest in the world.

title: Fireman's Fund Chief Suddenly Quits Post
description: Joseph W. Brown Jr., chief executive of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, resigned abruptly on Tuesday for personal reasons, saying only that he and his wife want to be closer to relatives on the East Coast. He will be replaced by Herbert Hansmeyer, chairman of Allianz of America, the United States unit of Allianz A.G. Holding of Munich, Germany, which acquired Fireman's a year ago for $3.3 billion in cash.

title: PRETORIA'S AIRLINE HIRES FEW BLACKS
description: Among the benefits South Africa reaped from the lifting of American economic sanctions last July was the restoration of landing rights for South African Airways in the United States.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. General information phone: (212) 963-1234 Tours are conducted 9 A.M.-5:45 P.M.

title: NO PROGRESS SEEN AT MIDEAST TALKS
description: The second day of Arab-Israeli peace talks in Washington concluded today with no visible progress on any front, but with none of the parties yet walking out and with the United States still leaving them to work out differences on their own.

title: Pohang Iron Debt Rating
description: The Pohang Iron and Steel Company, a Korean steelmaker known as Posco, has been assigned a debt rating of A+ on its implied senior debt previously unrated by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: YELTSIN REPORTED TO GAIN ADVANTAGE ON COMMONWEALTH
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appeared today to be losing his campaign to block creation of a commonwealth of former Soviet republics as the idea gained ground with additional republics.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * CDI Corp., Philadelphia, a holding company, said its CDI Temporary Services unit had acquired Today's Business Services Inc., Dallas, a temporary services concern. No terms were disclosed. * Esmark Inc., New York, said it had reached an agreement to buy Kidder International Inc., Seattle, a maker of water-sports equipment.

title: Claude Hill, Writer and Professor, 80
description: Claude Hill, a biographer of Bertolt Brecht who was a retired Rutgers University professor, died on Tuesday at Princeton Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: 73 Haitians Who Returned Home Were Rapidly Arrested, U.N. Says
description: A group of 73 Haitian refugees who returned voluntarily to the Haitian capital on Dec. 1 from temporary haven in Venezuela were arrested and interrogated by the police on their arrival, according to officials in the offices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees here and in Geneva.

title: ARMS ISSUE DRIVES U.S. SOVIET POLICY
description: While confident that there is no threat to American security from the Soviet upheaval, the Bush Administration believes the system of control over Soviet nuclear weapons is in danger of breaking down and that the breakaway republics have not yet worked out a way to replace it, officials said today.

title: Police Seek Ex-Worker at Attack Site
description: New York City police officials said yesterday that they wanted to talk with a former employee of a Brooklyn store that was the scene of vandalism and an attack on its Korean-American owner and his wife on Monday.

title: Messier Deal Is All Sewn Up
description: General Manager Neil Smith of the Rangers yesterday announced officially Mark Messier's new five-year, $13 million-plus-incentives contract, and the two also agreed that the struggling Rangers are not playing well enough to win the Stanley Cup in the spring.

title: Court Papers Link Election Chief to Scheme
description: The executive director of the New York City Board of Elections backdated campaign records last year that were submitted belatedly by a lawyer for a successful Brooklyn judicial candidate, court papers filed by the Manhattan District Attorney's office contend.

title: Big Bargains In Air Fares Grow Scarce
description: A year ago the nation's airlines, desperate to increase their winter business, were widely advertising bargains like two tickets for the price of one. Couples were flying coast to coast for just $214 a person.

title: Dinkins Aide Quits; May Run for Office
description: Saying that he wants to "pursue political opportunities," the New York City Personnel Director, Douglas H. White, resigned yesterday.

title: Ground Round Restaurants Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 655,000 for the quarter and $ 3,207,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary charge of $ 1,470,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 4,855,000.The company changed its audited fiscal year ended Sept. 29, 1991.

title: Greta Kempton Dies; A Portrait Painter, 89
description: Greta Kempton, a painter whose portrait of President Harry S. Truman hangs in the White House, died on Monday at her home in New York City. She was 89 years old.

title: Blue Chips Recover From an Early Selloff
description: In a turbulent session yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average nudged upward 1.56 points, to 2,865.38. After dropping sharply at midday, blue-chip stocks rebounded firmly in the afternoon, but smaller issues remained down.

title: Bio-Vascular Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on the early extinguishment of debt of $ 59,031.c-Net loss

title: Ex-Bookkeeper Is Accused
description: The former bookkeeper of the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, Lea Gilchinsky, was charged yesterday with embezzling $740,000 of the organization's funds. Ms. Gilchinsky, 43 years old, was the organization's bookkeeper from 1981 to August 1991. "She was discharged last August for other reasons," said Bert Fink, a spokesman for the Hammerstein Organization. The organization was founded by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d in 1945 and now administers the works of the musical team, including "Oklahoma," "The King and I," "South Pacific" and "The Sound of Music."

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Consolidated Limelight

title: Sea Beast Or Office Building?
description: THE Leviathan in Oakland, Calif., is the appropriately named office building that houses Ace Architects, a 13-year-old firm known for its highly thematic projects. Ace's founders, David Weingarten and Lucia Howard, designed the building to look like a sea monster.

title: Gold Medal Is Awarded To Seaport's Architect
description: The architect Benjamin C. Thompson has been awarded the 1992 American Institute of Architects Gold Medal, the institute has announced. He is to be presented with the medal at a ceremony on Jan. 22 at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Gifts: The Outside Story
Sports of The Times; Needed: Cure for Nightmare
description: JOE TAUB spoke from his car phone yesterday morning. I didn't ask where he was going, just assumed that anyone who was part-owner of the last-place New Jersey Nets was either out looking for a coach or some players. However, I did ask how he was doing.

title: Rushdie, Defying Death Threats, Suddenly Appears in New York
description: Suddenly and with no public warning, Salman Rushdie emerged from his life in hiding last night and implored an electrified assembly at Columbia University not to forget that he remains hostage to an Iranian sentence of death.

title: Bolar Settlement In Norwich Suit
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said it had reached a settlement with Norwich Eaton Pharmaceuticals Inc. to dismiss the charges filed against Bolar and its former chairman and chief executive, Robert Shulman. The settlement calls for Bolar to pay $3.4 million to Norwich Eaton in exchange for the dismissal of all claims against Bolar and Mr. Shulman. In a news release, Bolar said it would take a charge of the entire $3.4 million against 1991 income.

title: Key Rates

THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Accord Is Reached to Sell WFAN-AM for $70 Million
description: WFAN-AM, New York's all-sports radio station, is being sold by its cash-short owner, Jeffrey H. Smulyan, who encountered financial difficulties after acquiring the Seattle Mariners baseball team two years ago.

title: Johnson Products Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 256,000, or 22 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $ 174,000, or 15 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: New Jersey Panel Clears Officers in 2 Deaths
description: A statewide grand jury today found no basis for criminal charges against police officers who fatally shot two young Newark residents and wounded four others after a high-speed chase last June.

title: Seton Hall's Dehere Hurt In Victory Over Rutgers
description: The Seton Hall Pirates had to face some questions about themselves following an embarrassing 29-point defeat to North Carolina last week. Tonight, having to cope with the harsh and overwhelming noise of the Rutgers Athletic Center, the Pirates thought they found several solutions in their inspired 77-72 victory over the Scarlet Knights.

title: Yes Clothing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Should Take Lead on East Timor
description: To the Editor:

title: Events: Historic Houses And Holiday-Plant Sale
description: Orange County History Wesley Hall, 142 Clinton Street (off Route 211), Montgomery, N.Y.; (914) 457-3457.

title: Standard Brands Paint reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After income of $ 1,359,000, or 25 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net incomed-After a loss of $ 600,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Conde Nast Changes
description: Conde Nast Publications Inc. yesterday announced several top executive changes. Pamela van Zandt, vice president and corporate secretary, was named executive vice president. Ms. van Zandt joined Conde Nast in 1977 and was appointed director of personnel administration in 1979. Eric Anderson, vice president-treasurer, has been named executive vice president. Before joining Conde Nast in 1981, Mr. Anderson was controller of Random House. The appointments are effective immediately.

title: Agency Advertises For Mercedes Job
description: In an unusual effort to get into a review, Slater Hanft Martin, New York, is advertising to be considered for the Mercedes-Benz account and its more than $90 million in billings.

title: On Calling People by Their Rightful Names; No Conspiracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Starks Steps Up; Sonics Fall Back
description: As it turns out, there is a basketball team on 33d Street. As in T-E-A-M.

title: NEW YORK FAILING TO USE $600 MILLION FOR WATER SYSTEM
description: New York City's program to upgrade its long-neglected water mains, sewers and tunnels has fallen sharply behind schedule in the last year because the city's Environmental Protection Department has failed to let more than $600 million in contracts for the repair work -- almost half of the money budgeted for the purpose.

title: Audio/Video Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $ 4,775,000 from cumulative effect to Feb. 1, 1990, of change in service contract accounting.

title: Pacific Physician Services reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Orion Pictures Enters Bankruptcy Court
description: The Orion Pictures Corporation said today that it had filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors after long-running negotiations with its bondholders broke down.

title: Talking Deals; Putting a Value On Office Space
description: OLYMPIA & YORK, the giant Toronto-based real estate and energy company, set the New York commercial property markets buzzing recently when it announced one of the only large property deals in the city this year. But the announcement was so short on details that it raised more questions than it answered about the value of lower Manhattan office buildings.

title: Tax-Free Fund Yields Fall After Increase in Demand
description: Yields on tax-exempt money market funds began to retreat in the week ended yesterday, after rising in the previous seven-day period, according to the latest figures from IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and publishes The Money Fund Report. Taxable funds continued their long decline.

title: Democrats File Suit on Rule About Federal Campaign Aid
description: Charging political discrimination against Democratic Presidential candidates, the Democratic National Committee went to Federal District Court today to challenge Treasury Department regulations that set aside most existing Federal matching funds for the general election and party conventions, at the expense of primary campaigns.

title: Dow Up 29.75, to 2,895.13, After Retail Report
description: Stocks rose smartly yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 29.75 points, to 2,895.13. The Dow jumped in the morning in reaction to an unexpectedly upbeat retail sales report, then wavered somewhat at midday and rose gradually through the afternoon to close near the session high.

title: Casey Had Time to Meet Iranians in '80
description: To the Editor:

title: New F.C.C. Rule Aims At Phone Fees Abroad
description: The Federal Communications Commission adopted new rules today intended to prod foreign telephone companies to lower the high prices they charge to connect international calls from the United States.

title: Yes Clothing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Sybil Kooper, 66, Former Justice In New York Appellate Division
description: Sybil Hart Kooper, a retired justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in New York, died on Wednesday at her home in Brooklyn Heights. She was 66 years old.

title: Officers Face Perjury Case
description: Two New York City police officers were charged yesterday with perjury in connection with their arrest of a man on gun-possession charges. The officers, who were suspended, were accused of lying about where they found the gun they said was in his possession. The man was a three-time convicted felon, and another conviction would bring a mandatory life sentence under Federal sentencing rules. The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan brought the case against the two officers from the 43d Precinct -- James Gribben, 24 years old, and Carlos Maldonado, 28.

title: Clearing House Revamps Account
description: Publishers Clearing House, Port Washington, L.I., is looking for a second agency to handle the creative portion of its advertising account, said David Sayer, executive director for advertising and public relations.

title: KOREAS SIGN PACT RENOUNCING FORCE IN A STEP TO UNITY
description: Leaders of North and South Korea signed a treaty of reconciliation and nonaggression this morning, renouncing armed force against each other and saying that they would formally bring the Korean War to an end 38 years after the fighting ceased.

title: The Joyful Noises Of a Festive Season
description: THE music of Christmas makes only one demand on listeners: that they turn their attention either to the Christmas story itself or to the universal ideals of hope, peace and open-heartedness that the story is meant to convey. Yet if the focus of the music is singular, the wealth of the literature composed over the centuries to celebrate the season is remarkably varied.

title: The Mammoth Multiplexes of the Suburbs: How They Rate
description: Only suburbia could have invented a moviegoing system that is as easy as flipping the channel on a remote control. Suburban multiplexes are movie vending machines. Choice is king. A self-respecting multiplex will always offer at least 4 or 10 or 12 selections, and if there isn't something there for the whole family, you mustn't be from America.

title: Kasler Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said share net reflects 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: Israelis in East Jerusalem Occupy 6 Houses and Oust Arab Owners
description: A group of Israeli nationalists and a sizable police escort burst into Fatmeh Ahmad Karaim's house in one of East Jerusalem's larger Arab neighborhoods at dawn today and told her and her family of six that they did not live there anymore.

title: Critic's Choice/Film; Experimenting Together
description: Elliot Caplan's "Cage/Cunningham," a 100-minute film being shown at Anthology Film Archives through Dec. 29, is a knowing -- and indispensable -- exploration of the lives and work of the composer John Cage and the choreographer Merce Cunningham. Mr. Caplan, resident film maker at the Cunningham Studio, draws on extensive archival material, filmed rehearsals and performances, and recent interviews with Mr. Cage, Mr. Cunningham and their colleagues.

title: Bush Signs S.& L. Bill
description: President Bush today signed a bill providing $25 billion for four months to cover savings and loan failures, but he urged Congress to provide more when it returns next month.

title: Hardy Finally Signed
description: The Rangers yesterday put an end to one of their more embarrassing salary stalemates, finally signing 32-year-old defenseman MARK HARDY to a relatively modest $375,000 contract this season, with an option at the same figure next season.

title: Enjoying the 'Messiah'
description: Here is a sampling of performances and sing-ins of Handel's "Messiah" in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted.

title: Jack F. Kincannon, Retired Executive, 72
description: Jack F. Kincannon, a retired top executive of Sears, Roebuck & Company, died Dec. 3 at Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. He was 72 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Interpoint Corp. reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
At the Bar; But for the 14th Amendment, the Bill of Rights might not guarantee very much.
description: First came Caroline Kennedy on all the talk shows, promoting "In Our Defense: The Bill of Rights in Action," (Morrow) the best-seller she and a law school classmate wrote to dramatize issues like the death penalty and freedom of the press.

title: Robert W. Brooks, Bank Executive, 56
description: Robert W. Brooks, a managing director at Chemical Bank, died Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 56 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: Ennisteel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomec-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 679,784 in both the quarter and year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Yeltsin vs. Gorbachev: Soviet Leader Slipping
description: The long political rivalry between Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, appeared to have been decisively altered in Mr. Yeltsin's favor by the failed coup attempt against Mr. Gorbachev in August. But the Soviet leader counterattacked strongly, hoping to repair the damage to the concept of union, on which he had staked his political existence.

title: U.S. Urges Court's Approval To Resume Haitians' Return
